LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 

Islamic Republic of Pakistan 
 
The  proposed  subprogram  2  of  the  Punjab  Resource  Management 
Program  (PRMP)  consists  of  (i)  a  program  loan  of  $200  million  from 
Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB’s)  ordinary  capital  resources  (OCR) 
for  public  resource  management  reforms;  and  (ii)  a 
technical 
assistance  (TA)  grant  of  $150,000  to  support  the  preparation  of 
subprogram 3 of the PRMP. 
 
Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector:  Law, economic management, and public policy 
Subsector: Subnational or local government administration 
Themes: Governance, capacity development  
Subthemes: Public governance, organizational development

Support  from  subprogram  1  of  the  PRMP  improved  the  short-  to 
medium-term  fiscal  management  of  the  Government  of  the  Punjab 
(GOP) and also led to relatively robust local government development 
budgets.  These  achievements  enabled  higher  social  sector  spending 
and  helped  sustain  the  delegation  of  service  delivery  to  local 
governments under the devolution program. However, the incidence of 
poverty  in  Punjab  remains  high,  the  level  of  development  remains 
below its potential, and social indicators are poor. Sustainable growth 
to  address  these  concerns  requires  continuity  of  the  policy  and 
institutional reforms initiated under subprogram 1.  
 
Improvement  in  public  sector  governance  and  resource  management 
yields  considerable  development  gains.  In  the  context  of  the  current 
devolution, sustained assistance to provincial and local governments is 
required so they can adjust to their new roles. The focus needs to be 
on  policy  setting,  financing,  monitoring,  and  oversight  and  on  the 
realignment  of  systems,  procedures,  and  governance  structures. 
Subprogram  2  supports  such  reforms  and  is  in  line  with  the  medium-
term  budget  framework  developed  by  GOP.  The  emphasis  is  on 
improved  revenue-generating  capacity,  civil  service  reforms,  and 
private sector development. These will enable GOP to improve service 
delivery,  reduce  public  sector  employment  pressures,  and  support 
sustainable economic growth and poverty reduction.   
 
Subprogram  2  is  expected  to  be  completed  by  30  June  2007.  The 
overall PRMP is to be implemented by 30 June 2008. 
 
The goal of subprogram 2 is to improve fiscal and financial governance 
and public service delivery, leading to poverty reduction in Punjab. The 
purpose  and  policy  objectives  of  subprogram  2  are  to  assist  Punjab 
through reforms in governance structures, systems, and procedures to 
(i)  provide  “fiscal  space”  for  sustainable  development  and  improve 
monitoring mechanisms to ensure allocation and utilization of funds is

financial  management; 

effective  and  transparent;  (ii)  adjust  and  strengthen  institutional 
arrangements  to  increase  the  pro-poor  impact  of  public  expenditure 
and 
improve  service  delivery;  and  (iii)  create  a  conducive 
environment  for  private  sector  development,  growth,  and  income 
generation.  
 
Subprogram 2 will enable GOP to realize the policy agenda outlined in 
the  Punjab  Economic  Report.  That  agenda 
improving 
governance,  strengthening  fiscal  and  financial  structures,  developing 
the  private  sector,  ensuring  effective  public  service  delivery,  and 
reducing  the  economy’s  vulnerability  to  shocks.  Subprogram  2  builds 
on  other  ADB-financed  governance-related  programs,  such  as  the 
Decentralization  Support  Program  and  the  Devolved  Social  Services 
Program,  that  are  promoting  fiscal  devolution,  decentralized  social 
service delivery, local accountability, and gender reform.  
 
Subprogram 2 will support reform measures under three components: 
(i)  reforming  provincial  finances  through  fiscal  restructuring  and 
financial management; (ii) reforming processes and institutions for pro-
poor  service  delivery;  and  (iii)  creating  opportunities  for  growth  and 
income  generation  through  private  sector.  The  following  outputs  are 
envisaged  (i)  strengthened  provincial  revenues;  (ii)  rationalized 
provincial expenditures; (iii) improved effectiveness, predictability, and 
accountability 
(iv)  better  strategic 
programming of investments for poverty reduction; (v) restructured and 
strengthened  government,  administration,  and  human 
resource 
development;  (vi)  regulatory  and  administrative  reforms  for  private 
sector development; and (viii) reduced direct public sector involvement 
in economic and/or commercial operations. 
 
A  loan  of  $200  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources  will  be 
provided  under  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based 
lending  facility.  The  loan  will  have  a  15-year  term,  including  a  grace 
period  of  3  years,  an  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with 
ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility,  a  commitment  charge  for  the 
undisbursed  balance  of  0.75%  per  annum  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
standard  procedures,  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  and 
program agreements.  
 
The  Government  of  Pakistan  (the  Government)  will  onlend  the  local 
currency  generated  from  the  proceeds  of  the  loan  to  GOP,  at  terms 
and conditions similar to those given by ADB to the Government. The 
Government will assume the foreign exchange risk and GOP will bear 
the interest rate risk. 
 
Subprogram  2  will  be  completed  by  30  June  2007.  The  loan  will  be 
released in two equal tranches of $100 million each. The first tranche 
will be released upon satisfactory attainment of agreed achievements, 
on  the  date  of  loan  effectiveness  or  shortly  thereafter.  The  second 
tranche  will  be  available,  upon  satisfactory  attainment  of  agreed 
achievements,  within  18  months  from  loan  effectiveness.  The  closing 
date for withdrawals is 31 December 2007.

The  Planning  and  Development  Department  (P&DD)  of  GOP  will 
continue to be the executing agency for PRMP.  
 
P&DD  has  established  a  well  equipped  and  staffed  program 
management unit (PMU) to coordinate, facilitate, monitor, and evaluate 
overall implementation. P&DD will be responsible for administering the 
utilization  of  loan  proceeds.  It  will  deliver  a  draft  policy  matrix  for 
subprogram  3  as  a  second  tranche  condition  for  subprogram  2.  The 
PMU will function as the secretariat of the PRMP steering committee to 
be chaired by the chief secretary of GOP. The steering committee will 
provide  guidance  and  oversight  and  will  be 
for 
interdepartmental  and  policy  coordination.  It  will  liaise  with  the 
Government  to  ensure  that  the  PRMP  is  in  line  with  structural 
adjustment and governance initiatives at the federal level.  
  
The  loan  will  finance  foreign  exchange  costs  (excluding  local  duties 
and taxes) of imports procured in and from ADB’s member countries. 
The Government will certify that the value of eligible imports exceeds 
the amount of ADB’s projected disbursements under the program loan 
in  a  given  period.  ADB  will  have  the  right  to  audit  the  use  of  loan 
proceeds and to verify the accuracy of the Government’s certification.  
 
The  local  currency  counterpart  funds,  to  be  generated  from  the  loan, 
will  be  used  to  retire  expensive  provincial  debt.  The  savings  to  be 
generated  from  the  retirement  of  expensive  debt  will  be  used  to 
finance the cost of structural adjustment, establish funds and facilities, 
and  finance  high-priority  social  and  human  development  programs 
targeted at the poor. GOP will certify the utilization of counterpart funds 
in line with the loan agreement through audited statements acceptable 
to  ADB.  In  addition,  GOP  is  committed  to  use  its  own  resources  to 
capitalize pension and General Provident Funds.  
 
The purpose of the TA grant is to enable GOP to prepare subprogram 
3.  The  TA  will  assist  GOP  in:  (i)  fiscal  and  financial  management, 
(ii) civil service reforms, (iii) private sector development, and (iv) reform 
management and policy dialogue. The TA will enhance the capacities 
of the P&DD and key implementing agencies through lessons learned 
from the implementation of subprogram 2.  
 
The  total  cost  of  the  TA,  including  contingencies,  is  estimated  to  be 
$187,500 equivalent. ADB will finance $150,000 equivalent on a grant 
basis  from  ADB’s  TA  funding  program  to  cover  the  entire  foreign 
exchange cost and part of the local currency cost, mainly for domestic 
consultants.  GOP’s  contribution  will  be  20%  of  the  total  TA  cost.  The 
TA will require 3 person-months of international and 20 person-months 
of domestic consulting services.

Identifiable  benefits  will  accrue  over  the  medium  term  in  line  with  the 
outcomes detailed in the program framework and policy matrix. Specific 
and immediate impacts of subprogram 2 will include fiscal restructuring 
and utilization of loan proceeds to retire expensive provincial debt and to 
capitalize the pension and General Provident Funds. Subprogram 2 will 
also help the provincial civil service to be more responsive to clients. 
 
The  realization  of  benefits  will  depend  on  a  number  of  assumptions 
that  are  subject  to  a  variety  of  risks.  Mitigating  measures  have  been 
integrated  in  the  design  of  subprogram  2  as  appropriate,  taking  into 
account lessons learned from subprogram 1. 
 
Political  risks  in  Punjab  remain  comparatively  low.  The  elections  in 
October 2002 gave a clear majority to the party closely associated with 
the  administration 
initiated  Pakistan’s  reform  agenda.  The 
Government and GOP remain strongly committed to the PRMP.  
 
Subprogram  2  aims  to  reduce  abuses  of  power  and  rent-seeking 
opportunities.  Reforms  could  be  undermined  or  delayed  by  vested 
transparency  and

highest political level and in the civil services mitigates such risks.  
 
Insufficient  capacity  within  GOP  to  implement  the  envisaged  reforms 
has been addressed through arrangements for expeditious deployment 
of  specialist  assistance  and  capacity  building  support  under  an 
ongoing  ADB-financed  TA  loan  for  strengthening  public  resource 
management.  
 
While Pakistan’s macroeconomic indicators have been strong over the 
past  three  years,  poverty  levels  remain  high  and  must  be  reduced. 
Rising cost of oil, insecurity in the region, and the cost of earthquake 
reconstruction accentuate the macroeconomic risks. While some of the 
risks are beyond the control of the Government and GOP, prudent and 
consistent

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Pakistan  for  subprogram  2  of  the  Punjab  Resource  Management 
Program (PRMP). The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for supporting 
the preparation of subprogram 3 of the PRMP, and, if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, 
acting  under  the  authority  delegated  to  me  by  the  Board,  will  approve  the  TA.  The  program 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT1 

2. 
Significant Economic Recovery. Structural reforms were undertaken under a standby 
agreement in 2000. These were followed by a 3-year poverty reduction and growth facility of the 
International Monetary Fund in 2001. Since then, the economy has steadily improved. From a 
low of 1.8% growth in gross domestic product (GDP), at constant factor cost, in fiscal year (FY) 
2001, the economy grew by 8.4% in FY2005. This remarkable progress has been achieved as a 
result  of  the  consistency  and  continuity  of  the  economic  policy  framework  and  the  reform 
process.  Improvements  in  the  external  balance  of  payments,  credit  rating,  and  re-entry  into 
international  capital  markets  accompanied  this  accelerated  growth.  Monetary  expansion, 
coupled  with  a  buoyant  stock  market  and  greater  private  sector  participation,  reinforced  the 
growth  momentum.  Significant  gains  by  the  manufacturing  sector,  especially  by  large-scale 
manufacturing,  was  accompanied  by  fairly  good  performance  by  the  agriculture  and  services 
sectors. The overall growth enabled Pakistan to successfully complete and graduate out of the 
poverty reduction and growth facility in 2004. 2   
 
3. 
The  Government  of  Pakistan  (the  Government)  expects  the  economy  to  grow  by  more 
than 7% during FY2006. To sustain the growth momentum, the Government is taking steps to 
increase investment. Total investment grew at 16.9% in FY2005. Foreign direct investment has 
also  increased  significantly.  The  Government’s  privatization  program  alone  has  generated  net 
foreign  investment  of  over  PRs70  billion  in  FY2004  and  FY2005.3  With  good  rainfall,  the 
Government anticipates an increase of 50% in cotton production as well as a good wheat crop. 
 
Availability of Fiscal Space at the National Level. One of the biggest changes during 
4. 
the  last  few  years  has  been  the  creation  of  “fiscal  space”.  Debt  restructuring,  following 
renegotiation  through  the  Paris  Club;4  aid  and  soft-loan  inflows;  greater  foreign  remittance 
inflows through banking channels; and open market buying of US dollars by the State Bank of 
Pakistan  have  built  up  a  foreign  exchange  reserve  of  some  $12  billion.  The  fiscal  deficit  for 
FY2006  is  expected  to  remain  below  4%  of  GDP.  The  Central  Board  of  Revenue  is 
strengthening  tax  collection.5  In  FY2005,  collection  targets  were  met  and  a  record  amount  of 
PRs590 billion was collected. The target for FY2006 at PRs660 billion is likely to be met. On the 
expenditure side, the escalation of debt service payments has slowed because of better terms 
for foreign debt and a general reduction in interest rates. Nonetheless, with the rise in inflation, 
interest rates are rising.  

                                                 
1   For a more detailed analysis, see Asian Development Bank (ADB). 2005. Pakistan Economic Update. Islamabad; 

and State Bank of Pakistan. 2004. Annual Report. Islamabad.  

2  In June 2004, the International Monetary Fund completed the eighth review of Pakistan’s performance under the 3-

year poverty reduction and growth facility, and released $253 million. 

3   Based on the presentation of Dr. Hafeez Sheikh, Minister for Privatization to the Pakistan Development Forum on 

25 April 2005.  

4   An informal group of official creditors that renegotiates external debts.  
5   Changes in tax rates, tax administration, and collection were announced in the fiscal year (FY) 2006 budget.  

 2 

 

 

Poverty  Reduction  Remains  Top  Priority.  Despite  a  number  of  initiatives  aimed  at 
5. 
developing Pakistan’s economic and social sectors, the country’s level of development remains 
below  its  potential  and  social  indicators  are  poor.6  There  has  also  been  criticism  that  recent 
growth  has  neither  made  a  significant  impact  on  poverty  reduction  nor  generated  sufficient 
employment opportunities. A substantial part of employment is informal. High population growth 
has  led  to  increasing  numbers  of  unskilled  and  semi-skilled  workers  who  cannot  be  absorbed 
into  the  labor  market,  giving  rise  to  social  tensions  and  fueling  extremist  groups.7  To  counter 
these  trends,  the  Government’s  economic  policies  seek  to  uplift  livelihoods  and  create 
opportunities for the poor through support for employment-generating activities, more effective 
social sector spending, and more participation in local decision making.  
 
6. 
The Government has declared poverty reduction to be its overriding policy objective and 
has prepared a poverty reduction strategy (PRS) paper.8 A poverty partnership agreement with 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  signed  in  September  20029  sets  out  a shared  vision  and  key 
priorities  for  reducing  poverty  in  Pakistan.  Availability  of  fiscal  space  has  enabled  the 
Government to increase its social sector and poverty-related expenditure substantially in the last 
few  years,  from  PRs167  billion  in  FY2002,  to  PRs278  billion  in  FY2005,  and  an  anticipated 
PRs325 billion in FY2006, a 95% increase in the last 4 years. There are still questions about the 
absorptive  capacity  of  organizations  in  the  social  sector10  and  the  effectiveness  of  such 
expenditures,  but  Government’s  commitment  to  poverty  reduction  is  well  established,  and 
indicative  surveys  have  started  to  report  some  improvements,  including  a  decrease  in 
unemployment.11  
 
7. 
Far-Reaching  Governance  Reforms.  Governance  reforms  are  the  cornerstone  of  the 
Government’s  agenda  for  reducing  poverty.  The  previous  administration  embarked  on  an 
ambitious program of restructuring and reforming government institutions at all levels—federal, 
provincial,  and  local—and  a  bold  step  was  taken  with  the  devolution  plan  announced  by 
President Musharraf in 2000 and the promulgation of new local government ordinances (LGOs) 
by  all  provinces  in  2001.  These  reforms  will  have  a  fundamental  impact  on  identifying  and 
implementing development programs and allocating financial resources.  
 

III. 

THE SECTOR 

8. 
Public Resource Management and Governance. Although the first generation reforms 
at  the  federal  level  have  done  much  to  stabilize  Pakistan’s  macroeconomic  environment  in  
recent years, second-generation structural reforms at provincial and local government levels are 
required  to  deliver  the  social  and  other  public  services  needed  to  bring  about  a  direct  and 
sustained  improvement  in  the  quality  of  life.  Accordingly,  ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program 

                                                 
6   Pakistan  ranks  142  out  of  177  countries  in  the  Human  Development  Index.  Its  low  ranking  compared  to  other 
countries  with  similar  level  of  income  indicates  the  low  priority  that  social  sectors  have  historically  received.  See 
Mahbub ul Haq Human Development Centre. 2004. Human Development in South Asia 2004. Karachi. 

7  For  further  details  on  Pakistan’s  labor  market  and  challenges,  see  International  Labour  Organization.  2000. 

Pakistan Country Employment Policy Review. Islamabad.  

8  An  interim  poverty  reduction  strategy  (PRS)  paper  was  prepared  in  November  2001,  following  extensive 
consultation  with  stakeholders.  It  outlines  key  processes  to  be  set  in  motion  to  ensure  full  participation  in 
formulation  of  the  PRS  paper,  including  at  the  provincial  level  and  by  the  newly  elected  district  officials  and  civil 
society. Details on the interim PRS paper and an assessment of progress in finalizing the PRS paper can be found 
at http://www.imf.org. Currently, the Ministry of Finance is planning a revision of the PRS paper. 

9  ADB. 2002. Poverty Reduction Partnership Agreement between the Islamic Republic of Pakistan and ADB. Manila.

allocation and usage, could imply either wasteful expenditure or unspent resources at the end of the year. 

11  Preliminary  poverty  surveys  conducted  by  the  Government  show  some  improvements,  including  a  decrease  in 

unemployment.  

  

 

 3

update  (2006–2008)  for  Pakistan12  reiterates  the  need  for  continued  support  for  good 
governance,  sustainable  pro-poor  growth,  and  social  development.13  Emphasis  on  good 
governance is reflected in ADB funding for several key governance programs approved in the 
last  4  years  (Supplementary  Appendix  1).  Emphasis  on  good  governance  is  integral  to  public 
resource  management  reforms  that  emphasize  (i) sustainable  public  finance,  (ii)  effective  civil 
service, (iii) efficient and sufficient public service delivery, and (iv) private sector development.  
 
A. 

Sector Description and Performance 

9. 
Significance  of  Punjab.  Punjab  has  nearly  half  the  national  population  of  140  million 
and estimated 57% of the national GDP. Throughout 1990s, Punjab’s real GDP grew at 4.5% 
per annum, while the GDP growth for the country was 4.1%. Punjab has also led the country in 
the  recent  economic  recovery.  However,  the  per  capita  income  increase  by  about  2.1%  per 
annum  during  the  1990s  has  not  been  evenly  spread.  As  a  result,  despite  Punjab’s  good 
performance,  it  is  also  home  to  most  of  Pakistan’s  poor.  A  more  detailed  account  of  the 
socioeconomic sectors of Punjab is in Appendix 2. 
 
10. 
Opportunities for Sustainable Reforms. The stable macroeconomic environment, and 
the fiscal space at the national level in Pakistan, provides an opportunity for Punjab to achieve 
sustainable  growth  through  suitable  policies  and  institutional  reforms.  The  strategy  of  the 
Government  of  the  Punjab  (GOP),  as  formulated  in  the  Punjab  Economic  Report14  is  to:  (i) 
improve governance, (ii) strengthen fiscal and financial structures, (iii) create a more supportive 
environment  for  private-sector-led  growth,  (iv)  reform  the  delivery  of  public  services,  and  (v) 
address  the  vulnerability  of  the  province’s  economy  to  external  negative  factors.  PRMP 
subprogram  1  supported  GOP  to  take  action  on  some  of  these  elements.  Subprogram  2  will 
help implement GOP’s strategy outlined in Punjab Economic Report by formulating appropriate 
reform policies.15  
 
Key Functions of Provincial Government. Pakistan’s constitution places great weight 
11. 
on the delivery of public services by provinces, including social and physical infrastructure and 
associated  services.  Such  services  include  agriculture,  natural  resources  and  environmental 
management,  social  services,  physical  infrastructure,  economic  services  for  private  sector 
development,  and  asset  protection  and  public  order.  Good  coordination  between  federal  and 
provincial governments is required since some of these services may also be provided by the 
federal government. The constitution encourages the federal and provincial governments to take 
steps  to  improve  the  social  and  economic  status  of  women.  Major  service  functions  are 
delegated to local governments at district, tehsil16, and union levels.  
 
12. 
Impact  of  Decentralization  With  the  adoption  of  LGOs  in  2001,  primary  responsibility 
for  most  service  delivery  was  delegated  to  local  governments.  As  a  result,  provincial 
responsibilities have been redefined at all stages of public service delivery, including planning, 
financing, execution, and monitoring. Provincial governments have a key role in (i) ensuring that 
stable, predictable, and sufficient fiscal resources are made available; (ii) devising instruments 
for intergovernmental financing to encourage local government implementation of province-wide

integrated  and  sector-specific  service  delivery  (including  human  resources  policies),  while 
ensuring accountability and making certain that local authorities act according to the new legal 
and 
institutional  arrangements;  and  (iv)  enabling  effective  private-sector-led  economic 
development.  This  requires  an  adjustment  to  key  provincial  institutions  and  governance 
arrangements.   
 
13. 
total 
expenditures in FY2005 are estimated at PRs156 billion. Pakistan’s constitution limits provinces’ 
tax-raising powers, and GOP receives nearly 70% of its fiscal resources from federal transfers. 
Spending  policies  in  Punjab  have  been  more  conservative  than  those  of  other  provinces,  and 
the average fiscal deficit is estimated to be only 1–2% of provincial GDP. However, because of 
a  rigid  and  skewed  expenditure  structure,  as  well  as  inappropriate  planning,  budgeting,  and 
monitoring  mechanisms,  funds  have  increasingly  been  channeled  for  non-developmental 
expenditure, resulting in a progressive deterioration of public services and institutions.  
 
Intergovernmental  Fiscal  Transfers.  Most  taxes  and  other  forms  of  revenues  are 
14. 
collected by the federal government. The provinces receive a share of the revenues from these 
taxes  through  transfers.  The  list  of  taxes  that  contribute  to  the  pool  that  is  shared  with  the 
provinces,  the  provincial  and  federal  shares  of  the  pool,  and  the  formula  that  determines  the 
horizontal distribution of resources among the provinces are decided at least once every 5 years 
by the National Finance Commission (NFC). A new NFC award is expected to become effective 
in 2006, and it is anticipated that the provinces will share 48% of the “divisible pool.” Shared tax 
transfers  (out  of  the  divisible  pool)  account  for  75–80%  of  total  federal  transfers  to  GOP,  with 
the  remainder  comprising  other  direct  transfers,  loans,  and  grants.  Provincial  finance 
commissions (PFCs) have been established to allocate funds between the provinces and their 
local  governments.  The  allocation  is  based  on  a  number  of  criteria,  including  population,  area 
(to reflect population densities), relative poverty, and revenue effort,17 and is complemented by 
tied or incentive-matching grants to achieve development goals and protect crucial programs.  
 
15. 
Budgeting and Expenditure Management. Traditionally, budgets have been prepared 
annually and there has been little medium- or long-term planning. Unpredictability in timing and 
shortfalls in federal resource transfers have hampered budget implementation, and resulted in a 
shortfall of actual spending against targets. Expenditures are allocated in a mechanical way that 
does  not  adequately  reflect  policy  priorities  or  the  needs  of  citizens,  especially  the  poor.  The 
annual development program (ADP) has become overloaded with a large number of schemes 
with  doubtful  economic  returns  initiated  because  of  political  pressure.  This  has  resulted  in  a 
large portfolio of underfunded ongoing projects, with a spillover of commitments and huge time 
and  cost  overruns.  In  order  to  improve  financial  planning  and  expenditure  management, 
subprogram  1  supported  the  introduction  of  a  medium-term  budget  framework  (MTBF). 
However,  more fundamental changes in budgeting and expenditure management are required 
to align budget allocations with policy priorities and improve efficiency in implementation. 
 
16. 
Public Service Delivery Outcomes and Mechanisms. Lack of fiscal space has been a 
major  reason  for  the  continuous  deterioration  in  the  quality  of  public  services.  Public  services 
are  incapable  of  coping  with  a  growing  population  and  increasing  environmental  pressures. 
They  are  often  characterized  by  physical  inaccessibility,  facilities  in  a  poor  physical  condition, 
weak institutional management capacity, lack of community involvement, low service standards, 
lack of attention to gender equity, and poor staff quality. Human development and the physical

infrastructure-related  services,  credit, 

infrastructure are marked by a vicious cycle of shortage of funds, resulting in limited spending, 
service delivery, development, and willingness to pay. Processes and institutional arrangements 
that  are  still  rooted  in  the  administrative  system  that  preceded  Pakistan’s  independence  have 
resulted  in  rigid  and  control-oriented  procedures  at  the  provincial  level  that  are  inefficient, 
unsustainable, and unresponsive to the dynamic needs of society. A serious attempt to reform 
service  delivery  structures  began  with  the  recent  devolution  plan,  but  this  needs  to  be 
complemented by further measures at the provincial level. A considerable improvement in social 
sector indicators is needed if Pakistan is to achieve the Millennium Development Goals by 2015. 
 
17. 
Provincial–Private  Sector  Relations.  Although  there  have  been  numerous  policy 
statements  that  call  for  private  sector  development  and  the  investment  regime  has  been 
considerably liberalized over the past decade, there is still significant Government involvement 
at  the  policy  and  regulatory  levels  in  the  provision  of  infrastructure  and  economic  support 
services.  Regulatory  overlap  and  inconsistencies  remain  across  federal  and  provincial 
governments  and  institutions,  resulting  in  high  compliance  costs  for  businesses.  In  addition, 
imperfections in the legal system and in access to justice impede acquisition and disposition of 
property and the enforcement of contracts.  
 
Traditionally,  the  Government  favored  supply  of  cheap,  often  subsidized,  inputs, 
18. 
including 
inputs.  The 
Government  has  also  attempted  to  regulate  prices  of  outputs,  in  particular  for  agricultural 
produce. Government involvement has been mainly through about 130 autonomous bodies and 
public sector organizations (PSOs) that employ more than 100,000 people. The performance of 
these  PSOs  is  not  well  documented,  but  is  generally  considered  to  be  poor  and  their 
accumulated losses are estimated at about PRs35 billion. There is a realization that the role of 
Government needs to shift from providing key services directly to creating an environment that 
encourages private initiative and public–private partnerships for the delivery of public goods and 
services. 
 
19.   PRMP  and  Related  Programs.  ADB’s  strategy  for  its  support  to  Punjab  hinges  on 
governance  reforms  and  the  creation  of  fiscal  space,  leading  to  efficient  and  effective  public 
service  delivery  outcomes.  In  addition  to  the  PRMP,  the  Punjab  Devolved  Social  Services 
Program  (DSSP)18  aims  to  support  GOP  to  meet  its  social  sector  spending  targets  and  to 
improve mechanisms for fiscal transfers. The total financing available under the DSSP is $200 
million, consisting of $75 million from ADB’s Asian Development Fund, $75 million from ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources (OCR), and a $50 million grant from the Department for International 
Development  (DFID)  of  the  United  Kingdom.  As  agreed  with  GOP,  $75 million  has  been 
earmarked for formula-based transfers under the PFC to local governments, while $105 million 
would be used to implement GOP’s goal of sound provincial debt management and accelerated 
retirement of expensive  debt. Under the DSSP,  GOP agreed that fiscal savings accruing from 
reductions in interest rate charges will be invested in social sectors. DSSP further complements 
the PRMP policy objectives to increase social sector allocations in line with Punjab’s PRS and 
MTBF targets.  
 
In  addition,  the  World  Bank  is  supporting  GOP  through  two  Education  Sector  Reform 
20.  
Programs since 2004.19 These programs of $100 million each increase the funds available for 
education sector goals, such as higher primary school enrollment rates, especially for girls.

B. 

Issues and Opportunities  

21. 
GOP faces fiscal, governance, and institutional challenges. Some of these have already 
been  identified  under  subprogram  1,  and  work  to  address  them  has  already  begun.20  A 
successful response to the challenges could have a significant effect on the province’s ability to 
deliver  high-quality  public  services,  reduce  poverty,  and  improve  the  quality  of  life  for  a  large 
portion of the population.   

 
1. 

Fiscal 

 
22. 
Until a few years ago, as witnessed in the federal government and other provinces, total 
public spending in Punjab was being squeezed. On one hand, there were resource mobilization 
constraints at the provincial level and flows from the central divisible pool were limited. Some of 
these  constraints  continue.  On  the  other  hand,  ongoing  commitments  consumed  most 
revenues,  leaving  little  room  for  incremental  spending  or  for  adjusting  allocations  to  support 
policy priorities. Some of these issues were addressed under subprogram 1, with the result that 
revenues  from  taxes  within  provincial  control  increased  and  changes  in  expenditure  priorities 
were made. However, much remains to be done.  
 
23. 
Narrow  Tax  Base  and  Inefficient  Collection.  As  key  taxes  are  collected  and 
administered by the federal government, the provincial tax structure was characterized by many 
low-yielding,  inelastic  taxes  that  did  not  add  to  provincial  revenues.  The  share  of  provincial 
taxes  had  declined  over  the  years  to  less  than  7%  of  GOP’s  total  revenue  in  FY2003. 
Subprogram  1  identified  this  as  a  major  problem  and  set  targets  for  increased  local-source 
revenue for the province. In FY2005, the government local-source revenues grew by more than 
40%. Considerable potential for improvement remains, in particular for collection of agricultural 
income tax (AIT) and the introduction of a general sales tax on services. Since 2000, GOP has 
taken decisive steps to reform its provincial tax structure and has reduced the number of taxes 
from 36 to 9. It has changed assessments for agricultural income and is gradually introducing a 
general  sales  tax  on  services.  To  generate  returns,  reforms  in  the  tax  structure  need  to  be 
complemented  by  reforms  in  the  collection  system.  In  the  past,  tax  collection  has  been 
inefficient in part because of the large number of agencies involved. A review and consolidation 
of collection mechanisms would enhance transparency and effectiveness yielding considerable 
benefits. Making the AIT income-based or shifting to a presumptive tax21 could yield significant 
benefits for the province, and this is part of the reform agenda for subprogram 2.  
 
Unreliable  Intergovernmental  Fiscal  Transfers.  The  high  degree  of  dependence  on 
24. 
federal  transfers  leaves  provincial  governments  exposed  to  national  policies  and  federal 
performance,  with  little  leeway  to  compensate  for  shortfalls  in  such  transfers.  The  volatility  of 
transfers from the federal government’s divisible pool makes provincial revenue and expenditure 
estimates  unrealistic.  However,  partly  because  of  higher  economic  growth  rates  and  a  better 
performance from the federal revenue administration system, revenue transfers to the provinces 
have  improved  substantially  and  have  been  in  line  with  the  budgeted  receipts,  resulting  in  a 
sharp decline in the unpredictability and volatility of transfers. The new NFC award, expected to

25.   With  fiscal  decentralization,  much  spending  authority  has  been  delegated  to  local 
governments.  A  key  challenge  is  to  develop  a  sustainable,  transparent,  and  effective 
intergovernmental  transfer  mechanism.  The  first  steps  have  been  taken  at  the  provincial  level 
with the establishment of PFCs and the introduction of block allocations to districts. Some of the 
basic requirements for supporting the devolution framework have been met under subprogram 
1, but much remains to be done on matters pertaining to administrative and financial reform and 
enhancing governmental capacity to deliver social and public services of an acceptable quality. 
The  ongoing  Decentralization  Support  Program  (DSP)23 
the  provincial 
governments  to  finalize  the  PFC  awards  through  focused  TA  and  continued  policy  dialogue. 
Subprogram 2 complements and reinforces this process by seeking assurances from GOP that 
development  budgets  will  be  transferred  to  local  governments  in  a  predictable,  timely,  and 
transparent manner. Under PRMP, GOP will complete the establishment of the PFC before the 
end of 2005. It will allocate PRs99 billion partly according to a formula and partly to reward the 
better performing local governments. 
 
26. 
Skewed  and  Rigid  Expenditure  Structure  and  Unfunded  Liabilities.  On  the 
expenditure side, flexibility is limited by high operating costs (salaries and pension payments), 
which  account  for  more  than  half of  total spending.  This is  a  result  of  an  overextended,  partly 
uneconomic,  public  infrastructure  and  overstaffed,  ineffective  social  service  networks  that  are 
fiscally  unsustainable.  The  servicing  of  provincial  debt  as  a  percentage  of  the  total  provincial 
expenditures continues to decrease and dropped from 13.5% in FY2000 to an estimated 9% in 
FY2006.  This  is  partly  because  of  the  increase  in  provincial  revenues  and  partly  because  of 
measures such as early retirement of cash development loans (supported under subprogram 1). 
The provincial government continues to take steps to limit further increases in operating costs, 
reduce subsidies, and implement its debt management strategy.   
 
27. 
Increase of Liabilities. Punjab’s debt has increased considerably over the past decade, 
and  there  was  an  accumulated  debt  stock  of  PRs162.6  billion  at  the  end  of  FY2005.  A  large 
portion of this, PRs67.5 billion, was financed by cash development loans with high interest rates 
(some above 17% per annum). Refinancing of liabilities was initiated through subprogram1 and 
so  far  PRs5.76  billion  of  expensive  cash  development  loans  has  been  retired.  GOP  needs  to 
implement  its  debt  reduction  strategy  to  make  the  debt  burden  more  manageable  and  create 
fiscal  space  to  re-prioritize  its  expenditures.  Although  GOP  could  use  the  proceeds  of 
subprogram  2  for  the  same  purpose,  it  also  needs  to  establish  dedicated  funds  to  cover  its 
unfunded and contingent liabilities. In particular, the unfunded liabilities of the pensions and the 
General Provident Funds need to be addressed urgently. Now that some fiscal space has been 
created for Punjab in the last couple of years, GOP needs to take a close and critical look at its 
expenditure  priorities  so  that  actual  expenditures  can  be  brought  into  line  with  the  priorities 
identified by the medium-term vision of the government. 
  
28. 
Inefficient  Subsidies.  The  major  subsidy  provided  by  GOP  is  for  wheat  prices. 
However,  this  is  not  targeted  at  the  poor.  In  fact,  it  leads  to  market  distortion,  as  the 
Government  buys  wheat  expensively  (and  bears  storage  and  transportation  costs)  and  sells it

2.  

Governance and Institutional Issues 

 
Although  the  Punjab  LGO  was  promulgated  in  2001,  putting  administrative  and 
29. 
institutional changes in place will take time. Local governments have been empowered to take 
over  a  number  of  important  functions,  especially  those  related  to  provision  of  local  public 
services. Significant changes are still needed in the administration, institutional structure, and in 
rules,  regulations,  and  laws  related  to  local  administration.  Subprogram  2  will  continue  to 
support GOP to achieve specific targets in this regard. 
 
30.  More  Private  Sector  Involvement.  To  improve  the  coverage  and  quality  of  services, 
water supply, sanitation, road construction, and maintenance could be partially provided by the 
private sector. The potential for public–private partnerships is being explored. Subprogram 2 will 
help GOP to work more closely with the private sector by (i) facilitating governance structures in 
specific  sectors,  (ii)  amending  rules  and  laws  governing  such  activities,  and  (iii) establishing 
institutional  arrangements  to  improve  links  with  institutions  such  as  the  Punjab  Health 
Foundation. Continuing the work of subprogram 1, subprogram 2 will work with GOP to further 
reduce direct public sector involvement, especially through an action plan to restructure PSOs 
owned by GOP. 
 
31.   A major impediment to private sector development is the inability of companies to secure 
land  assets.  In  Pakistan,  the  management  of  land  records  faces  two  fundamental  problems: 
(i) maintenance of records is poor and records are updated only after a considerable time-lag, 
and  (ii)  the  records  contain  only  presumptive  title  holders  on  the  title  documents.  These 
problems reduce the value of the title document and restrict the use of land for collateral. A vast 
amount of valuable resources cannot be used as security to finance the needs of businesses. 
Under subprogram 2, GOP will improve the maintenance of the land records by automating the 
property  record  and  property  tax  collection  databases  in  the  urban  areas  through  selected 
TMAs. A World Bank study is attending to similar issues for the rural areas. Both initiatives are 
expected  to  improve  the  business  environment  substantially  and  to  increase  private  sector 
development.  
 
32. 
Ineffective  and  Rigid  Administrative  Structures.  The  public  sector  as  a  whole  is 
overextended.  Punjab’s  public  sector  employs  nearly  1  million  people,  most  of  whom  are 
employees  of  GOP.  There  are  about  862,000  official  positions  in  education,  health,  police, 
irrigation,  and  agriculture.  The  administrative  structure  is  centralized  and  does  not  allow  for 
flexibility in responding to needs, in particular in those areas where services are delivered at the 
local  level.  Most  employees  are  at  lower  salary  grades,  including  20%  at  grade  1,  which  is 
essentially unskilled staff, and 40% at low-skilled grades 2–5. As a result, the bureaucracy has 
become  unmanageable,  with  considerable  duplication  of  functions.  Efforts  by  GOP  to  address 
these  shortcomings,  as  well  as  the  development  of  a  civil  service  reform  strategy,  will  be 
supported under subprogram 2.  
 
Tackling  Rent-seeking  Behavior.  Rent-seeking  takes  place  when  uncompensated 
33. 
value  is  extracted  from  others  by  manipulating  the  economic  environment.  Rent-seeking 
opportunities  exist  in  all  societies  and  come  in  different  forms  (from  creating  economic 

  

 

 9

distortions  through  favoritism  to  share  value  manipulation).  In  Pakistan,  because  of  the  low 
salaries and lack of accountability, public servants indulge in rent-seeking activities that have a 
direct impact on the poor by reducing their disposable income after rents have been extracted 
from the system. Another major cause of rent-seeking in the public sector is low budgets for the 
operational  costs  of  running  public  services.  These  low  budgets  encourage  rent-seeking 
behavior so that operational costs can be funded. Subprogram 2 includes four major activities 
that  will  assist  Punjab  to  decrease  rent-seeking:  (i)  greater  accountability  as  a  result  of  better 
procurement rules and regulations that require all procured goods to be listed as unit costs on 
GOP official procurement website; (ii) the introduction of public expenditure tracking surveys to 
identify  leaks  from  budgets  to  “frontline”  service  providers;  (iii)  the  establishment  of  a  change 
management unit (CMU) to help GOP identify opportunities for restructuring the civil service and 
making it more efficient and accountable; and (iv) a progressive increase in operational budgets 
to minimize rent-seeking caused by the need to finance operational costs. 
 
34. 
Human  Resources  Management  and  Accountability.  The  weak  performance  of 
Punjab’s  public  institutions  is  largely  a  reflection  of  inadequate  human  resources  policies  and 
management, and lack of accountability. In many cases, staff do not have the skills to perform 
the  functions  they  are  assigned  to  carry  out.  This  is  partly  because  of  frequent  rotations  of 
staff—despite  the  recently  announced  minimum  tenure  policy  by  the  cabinet—as  well  as 
appointments made under political pressure. GOP has recently issued a revised appointments 
policy  and  increased  the  number  of  services  that  are  contracted  to  the  private  sector,  a  trend 
that needs to be continued. However, promotion policy and guidelines are not clear, and, in the 
absence of clear accountability, rules, and performance monitoring systems, upward mobility of 
staff is still based more on seniority than on performance. Together with a highly  compressed 
wage  structure  that  has  not  kept  pace  with  market  trends,  especially  for  positions  of 
responsibility,  it  has  become  increasingly  difficult  to  attract  and  retain  suitable  talent  for  key 
institutions. However, Punjab has a large human resources pool to tap into, and improvements 
in  human  resources  policy,  combined  with  greater  outsourcing  to  the  private  sector  (using 
clearly defined performance criteria) could yield considerable efficiency gains.  
 
35. 
Another  serious  challenge  for  GOP  since  the  devolution  of  powers  in  2001  is  the 
streamlining  of  the  provincial  civil  service.  Currently,  most  local  government  technical  and 
administrative  staff  are  recruited  and  managed  by  the  provincial  government,  which  distorts 
accountabilities  at  the  local  level.  This  has  serious  implications  for  local  government  human 
resources management and public service delivery. Under the revised legal framework, GOP is 
mandated  to  create  and  support  a  district  civil  service  in  order  to  remove  these  distortions. 
PRMP will work with GOP to do this and through the TA program, ADB will help GOP to prepare 
a workable and efficient human resources policy with a medium- to long-term vision. The CMU 
to be established under subprogram 2 will also play a role in rationalizing and reforming the civil 
service at the provincial and local levels. 
 
36. 
Gender  Inequalities.    The  provincial  governments  are  committed  to  gender  equality 
and,  in  consultation  with  the  federal  government,  have  prepared  gender  reform  action  plans 
(GRAPs). These contain gender commitments made by the federal and provincial governments 
through  four  central  themes:  (i)  improving  the  representation  and  participation  of  women  in 
political and administrative structures; (ii) moving from social welfare to women’s development 
and  eventually  to  gender  equality;  (iii) restructuring  provincial  and  district  government 
arrangements  from  a  gender  perspective;  and  (iv)  using  planning  and budgetary  processes to 
narrow  the  gender  gap.  GOP  has  recently  approved  a  major  program  to  fund  the  actions 
proposed in GRAP. To ensure that there is continuity in these gender-related reforms, there is 

 10 

 

 

an  urgent  need  to  coordinate  the  implementation  of  the  GRAP  with  subprogram  2 
(Supplementary Appendix 2).  
 

3. 

Lessons Learned  

37. 
The  formulation  and  design  of  subprogram  2  build  on  the  institutions,  mechanisms, 
experiences, and achievements of subprogram 1. Subprogram 2 also benefits from the lessons

Strong  leadership,  ownership,  and  consultation.  To  succeed,  the  reforms 
must  be  designed,  owned,  and  implemented  by  stakeholders,  especially  GOP 
and its departments. Accordingly, high-level support has been integrated into the  
subprogram  2  design  through  the  steering  committee  chaired  by  the  chief 
secretary.  The  reform  agenda  was  developed  by  GOP  and  was  expanded 
through  two  Punjab  Development  Forums  (16-17  September  2003,  18-19  April 
2005)  to  enable  broad-based  stakeholder  participation.25  There  have  also  been 
extensive consultations with representatives from civil society, the private sector, 
the media, and other partner organizations. 

Improved coordination, facilitation, and monitoring. Stakeholder coordination 
is  required  to  maintain  and  enhance  aid  effectiveness  and  avoid  overlaps.  To 
ensure this, a provincial reform coordination office under the chief secretary has 
been  operational  since  September  2005  to  coordinate  the  interventions  of 
international development partners as well as between various GOP departments 
involved in implementing PRMP.  

Effective  management  of  change.  The  fundamental  nature  of  PRMP  reforms 
requires  a  coordinated  change  management  process  for  a  phased  and 
sequenced implementation with stakeholder support at all stages. Accordingly, a 
CMU under the chief secretary will be set up with emphasis on feedback from all 
levels of the civil service. This feedback will serve to refine policy reforms during 
subprogram 2, as well as to define the reform agenda for subprogram 3.  

Enhanced  communication  on  policy  reforms.  Dissemination  of  reforms  and 
outcomes  is  important  for  reducing  resistance  to  change  and  enabling  a  wider 
consensus. Subprogram 2 will provide regular and targeted information on policy 
reforms  at  the  PRMP  website.  The  program  management  unit  (PMU)  will  also 
develop  a  time-bound  media  plan  including  translation  into  local  languages  to 
effectively articulate reforms to a wider audience.

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 

39. 
Under  subprogram  1,  the  GOP  managed  to  achieve  effective  short-  to  medium-term 
fiscal  management.  This  enabled  higher  social  sector  spending  and  relatively  robust  local 
government  development  budgets.  However,  long-term  resource  management  will  require 
improvements  in  the  policy  making  environment.  Long-term  change  management  can  only  be 
sustained  through  a  professional  and  accountable  civil service.  In  addition,  effective  long-term 
resource  management  will  entail  rationalizing  the  role  of  the  public  sector,  taking  into  account 
the  current  and  future  liabilities  of  GOP,  and  the  need  to  improve  its  revenue  generating 
capacity.  Facilitating  private  sector  development  will  enable  GOP  to  improve  service  delivery, 
reduce  public  sector  employment  pressures,  and  support  sustainable  economic  growth. 
Subprogram  2  will  support  this  agenda  in  line  with  the  medium-term  budget  framework 
developed by GOP (Appendix 5 and Supplementary Appendix 4). 
 
40. 
Subprogram 2 formulation was coordinated with stakeholder from various levels of GOP, 
civil  society,  private  sector,  NGOs,  and  development  partners.  The  GOP  is  fully  committed  to 
the  subprogram  2  reform  agenda.  The  program  framework  is  in  Appendix  1,  and  the 
development policy letter and policy matrix are in Appendix 4. 
 
A. 

Impact and Outcome   

41. 
Governance  Reforms  for  Poverty  Reduction.  The  goal  of  the  subprogram  2  is  to 
improve fiscal and financial governance and public service delivery, leading to poverty reduction 
in Punjab. Subprogram 2 seeks to support the GOP to realize the policy agenda outlined in the 
Punjab  Vision  2020,26  the  Punjab  Economic  Report  (footnote  14),  and  the  national  PRS. 
Technical support will be provided to GOP to undertake policy and institutional reforms and to 
effectively manage change management process. Subprogram 2 will build on other governance-
related programs such as the DSP (footnote 23) and the DSSP (footnote 18) that promote fiscal 
devolution, decentralized social service delivery, local accountability, and implementation of the 
provincial gender reform action plan.  
 
42. 
Realign Governance Structures, Systems, and Procedures.  The purpose and policy 
objectives  of  subprogram  2  are  to  assist  Punjab  through  reforms  in  governance  structures, 
systems, and procedures to: 

(i)  

(ii)  

provide  fiscal  space  for  sustainable  development  and  improve  monitoring 
mechanisms for effective and transparent allocation and utilization of funds; 
adjust and strengthen institutional arrangements to increase the pro-poor impact 
of public expenditure and improve service delivery; and

economic or commercial nature. 

 
43. 
Program Cluster Modality. The PRMP cluster modality consists of three subprograms 
with each subprogram divided into three components with specified key result areas (KRAs): (i) 
reforming  provincial  finances  through  fiscal  restructuring  and  financial  management;  (ii) 
reforming processes and institutions for pro-poor service delivery, and (iii) creating opportunities 
for growth and income generation through private  sector development. The second tranche of 
the two tranche subprogram 1 was released in June 2005. Of the 22 second tranche conditions, 
the GOP fully complied with 18 and substantially complied with 4 (Supplementary Appendix 5). 
The  GOP  remains  committed  to  complying  fully  with  the  4  conditions  that  were  assessed  as 
substantially complied.  
 
44. 
Subprogram  2,  consisting  of  two  tranches,  builds  on  subprogram  1  by  targeting  11 
outcomes  to  allow  for  a  streamlined  focus  on  the  key  priorities  of  GOP  (paras.  46-66),  as 
identified  in  the  development  policy  letter  (Appendix  4),  particularly  in  fiscal  and  financial 
management,  procurement,  and  civil  service  reforms.  Subprogram  2  also  emphasizes  on 
capacity development of the executing and implementing agencies to implement the proposed 
reforms and to help GOP to develop further reform solutions to be supported under subprogram 
3. Use of the sizeable TA27 resources provided by ADB and DFID will support capacity building.  
 
B.

economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction  and  supporting  private  sector  development.  Table  1 
presents  an  overview  of  focal  areas  under  each  of  the  seven  KRAs.  Further  details  on  the

1.  

 

Reforming Provincial Finances through Fiscal Restructuring and Financial 
Management 

a. 

KRA 1: Strengthen Provincial Revenues 

 
46. 
Progress  to  date.  GOP  implemented  major  reforms  to  consolidate,  restructure,  and 
enhance  collection  of  provincial  taxes  and  other  revenues  to  provide  the  basis  for sustainable 
provincial  revenue.  The  major  result  was  an  increase  in  provincial  tax  receipts  in  FY2004  by 
more  than  44%  in  nominal  terms,  reflecting  higher  levels  of  provincial  revenue-generating 
responsibilities  as  part  of  the  overall  devolution  process  in  Pakistan.  The  much  higher  than 
envisaged  increase—a  minimum  of  12%  was  targeted—was  achieved  by  (i)  broadening  the 
base  of  professional  tax  by  including  lawyers,  jewelers,  and  wholesale  tobacco  dealers; 
(ii) revising  the  urban  immovable  property  tax  (UIPT);  (iii)  revising  stamp  duty  collection;  and 
(iv) introducing a flat rate abiana (irrigation water charge). Subprogram 2 will continue to support 
reforms to strengthen provincial revenues.  
 
47. 
Outcome 1: Broaden Tax Base: Rationalize and Restructure Provincial Taxes and 
Duties. Under subprogram 2, the tax structure and rates will be rationalized to increase annual 
provincial tax revenues by at least 14% in FY2006 and by 16% in the budget for FY2007. Efforts 
to  increase  the  collection  of  AIT  will  be  supported  and  the  UIPT  rates  will  be  increased.  The 
Excise and Taxation Department (E&TD) will phase-in rationalization of the tax rate, simplify tax 
assessment  and  collection,  and  reduce  differential  tax  rates  between  owner-occupied  and 
rented commercial and residential properties. E&TD will also formulate a policy to revise the tax 
assessment valuation table every 3 years, based on the UIPT index assessment. The revision 
to the valuations will take account of inflation and ensure that the tax base remains realistic and 
buoyant. Capacity development of the Board of Revenue (BOR) will ensure that the targets for 
taxation reform are achievable. BOR will also simplify, rationalize, and enhance the elasticity of 
stamp duty by reducing the number of serials and exemptions and converting flat rate duties to 
ad valorem duties. 
 

b. 
 

KRA 2: Rationalize Provincial Expenditures 

48. 
Progress  to  date.  Subprogram  1  helped  to  change  GOP’s  expenditure  pattern  by  re-
profiling debt and building a long-term strategy to gradually reduce the servicing of debt. Within 
the  first  year  of  PRMP,  there  was  an  increase  in expenditures on high-priority social sector  
 

 14 

 

 

interventions. In the GOP white paper, 2004–2005, budgetary allocations for FY2005 increased 
over the previous year by 19.8% for health, 28.4% for education, and 591.0% for water supply. 
Allocations  in  the  ADP  for  FY2005  increased  over  the  previous  year  by  37.7%  for  education, 
132.6% for health, and 167.1% for water supply.  These developments were directly supported 
by (i) reducing the provincial debt by retiring cash development loans using the proceeds of the 
first tranche of the PRMP; (ii) reducing contingent liabilities (e.g., limiting the GOP’s guarantee 
of  loans  to  PSOs  and  establishing  a  separate  General  Provident  Fund;  (iii) restructuring  and 
rationalizing  government  subsidies  by  phasing  out  subsidies  that  do  not  explicitly  target  the 
poor;  and  (iv)  rationalizing  the  ADP  and  making  it  consistent  with  availability  of  funds  in  the 
MTBF  projections.  Subprogram  2  will  further  rationalize  expenditures  and  continue  to  create 
fiscal space through debt restructuring 
 
Outcome 2:   Reduce Provincial Debt and Contingent Liabilities. To reduce its debt 
49. 
burden,  GOP  will  accelerate  the  retirement  of  expensive  domestic  public  debt.  It  is  projected 
that debt servicing of interest only will be reduced from 6.4% of current expenditures in FY2005 
to 5.0% in FY2006. GOP is committed to establishing a legal and regulatory framework for the 
capitalization of both the pension fund and the General Provident Fund. It is expected that GOP 
will capitalize the pension and General Provident Funds with an amount of at least PRs12 billion 
by the end of subprogram 2.  
 
Outcome 3:   Re-prioritization of Expenditures to Improve Public Service Delivery.  
50. 
Subprogram  2  will  focus  on  ameliorating  the  chronic  problems  of  low  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) budgets and inadequate non-salary budgets28 that have impeded effective 
service  delivery  outcomes  and  encouraged  rent-seeking  behavior.  In  the  past,  O&M29 
allocations  have  been  less  than  5%  of  current  expenditures  and  non-salary  allocations  have 
been less than 9%. GOP is committed to increasing expenditure on O&M to at least 8% and on 
non-salary expenditures to at least 12% of current expenditures.

Outcome 5:  Transparent  and  Efficient  Procurement  of  Goods  and  Services. 
Subprogram 2 will focus on transparent and efficient procurement of goods and services. During 
the next 12 months, the annual procurement plans of the Services and General Administration 
Department  (S&GAD),  the  Health  Department,  and  possibly  others  will  be  posted  on  GOP’s 
procurement website. S&GAD will standardize common procurement items and will update the 
purchase manual. These activities will be based on international best practices and procedures 
for  procuring  goods  and  services.  Capacity  development  of  S&GAD  will  be  undertaken  at  the 
same  time.  GOP  will  notify  departmental  purchase  committees  through  amendments  to  the 
purchase manual on the eligibility criteria for pre-qualifying suppliers based on international best 
practices. It will design specifications for tenders and evaluate tender bids based on transparent 
and  defensible  criteria.  Clear  dispute  resolution  criteria  will  be  inserted  into  the  updated 
purchase manual. Subprogram 2 will further facilitate the posting of unit costs of procured goods 
on the official government website.

tenants  and  role  of  the  rent  controller  is  reduced  in  eviction  proceedings  (eviction  should  be 
governed  by  contract  and  breaches  should  be  decided  by  the  relevant  court).  The  BOR  will 
initiate  a  technical  study  of  urban  land  titling  systems  in  order  to  improve  documentation  and 
provide  greater  security  for  and  transparency  of  property  rights  and  systems  for  property 
registration. E&TD will formulate a policy with a phased, time-bound action plan for automation 
of  urban  property  records  and  property  tax  collection  systems  in  five  TMAs  (e.g., Lahore, 
Rawalpinidi,  Gujranwala,  Faisalabad,  and  Sialkot).  These  reforms  will  lead  to  higher  property 
tax collection, minimize rents, and result in secure land titling.  

 
g. 

KRA 7: Reduce Direct Public Sector Involvement in Economic and/or 
Commercial Operations 

 
65. 
Progress to date. Under subprogram 1, studies were undertaken to assess the public 
liabilities  of  the  province  and  its  PSOs.  Recommendations  of  the  studies  will  be  implemented 
during subprogram 2. 
 
66. 
Outcome 11:  Reform  of  PSOs  Involved  in  Economic  and  Commercial  Activities: 
Restructure, Privatize, or Close. GOP restructured the Punjab Mineral Development Board in 
2005  as  part  of  subprogram  1.  It  is  currently  restructuring  the  Punjab  Provincial  Cooperative 
Bank.  Under  subprogram  2,  GOP  will  restructure  the  Agricultural  Research  Board,  the  Punjab 
Library Foundation, and the Punjab Privatization Board. It will restructure small industrial estates

under  the  Pakistan  Small  Industries  Corporation  by  transferring  the  management  of  small

C. 
 
67. 
As part of PRMP, subprogram 2 is a critical link between what has been achieved during 
subprogram 1 and what is expected during subprogram 3. As envisaged at the design of PRMP, 
the cluster modality has enabled a dynamic development process by integrating various reform 
initiatives  over  a  medium-term  time  frame,  while  allowing  flexibility  for  performance-based 
adjustments.  The  effective  short-  to  medium-term  fiscal  management  achieved  during 
subprogram  1  indicates  that  creating  fiscal  space  is  a  better  development  intervention  than 
financing  incremental  expenditures.  In  addition,  subprogram  2  integrates  the  key  elements  of 
ADB’s poverty reduction, private sector development, governance, gender, and anti-corruption 
strategies. The expected impact of subprogram 2 is considerably enhanced by building on other 
ADB-financed governance-related programs, such as the DSP and DSSP, which promote fiscal 
devolution, decentralized social service delivery, local accountability, and gender reform.

Loan Amount and Standard Terms and Conditions. The Government has requested

accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,  a

choices were its own independent decision and not made in reliance on any communication or 
advice from ADB.

5.  

Sustainability 

PRMP  has  already  helped  to  bring  about  significant  reforms  in  development  planning 
85. 
and resource management systems in Punjab. GOP has taken significant steps in this regard, 
initiating important reforms including the introduction of an MTBF, taxation reforms, reforms of 
the procurement of goods and services, improvements to the planning and approval process for 
development  projects  with  a  poverty  focus,  and  the  approval  of  a  new  industrial  policy  that 
addresses  many  of  the  concerns  of  the  private  sector.  Under  subprogram  1,  initial  steps  to 
increase the pro-business orientation of legal instruments and to reduce bureaucratic discretion 
have  already  improved  the  business  climate.  Subprogram  2  will  build  on  and  support  GOP  to 
implement an essentially homegrown reform agenda. Given GOP’s strong sense of ownership 
of  the  reform  process,  the  prospects  for  the  long-term  sustainability  of  the  PRMP’s 
achievements are good.

VI.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Benefits 

Subprogram  2  is  expected  to  yield  significant  benefits  by  supporting  a  comprehensive 
97. 
change in public service delivery. Sustainable pro-poor public service delivery will be derived from 
(i) actions that improve fiscal discipline and allow more spending on high-priority poverty reduction 
measures;  (ii) better  governance  mechanisms,  institutional  arrangements,  and  accountability  for 
expenditure  management  and  service  delivery;  and  (iii)  an  environment  that  offers  more 
opportunities for growth, employment, and income generation. Identifiable  benefits  will  accrue 
over  the  medium  term  in  line  with  the  outcomes  detailed  in  the  program  framework  and  policy 
matrix.  Subprogram  2  will  have  specific  and  immediate  impacts  on  fiscal  restructuring  and 
utilization of loan proceeds to capitalize the pension and General Provident Funds. Subprogram 2 
will help the provincial civil service to become more responsive to the needs of the population.  
 

 24 

 

 

GOP  has  commenced  reforms  by  preparing  an  MTBF,  reforming  taxation,  improving 
98. 
procurement  procedures,  and  approving  a  new  industrial  policy  that  addresses  many  of  the 
concerns  of  the  private  sector.  Initial  steps  to  make  orientation  of  the  legal  instruments  under 
subprogram 1 more pro-business have already improved the business climate. With the current 
pace  of  reforms  and  the  long-term  commitment  of  GOP,  sustainability  is  embedded  in  the 
reform process.  
 
B. 

Impacts 

99. 
Subprogram 2 is expected to have a positive impact on poverty reduction by facilitating a 
shift toward more social sector spending (Appendix 9). The impact on labor markets, prices, net 
public transfers, and access to public goods and services is expected to be positive in the long 
term. There are no significant adverse impacts directly associated with Subprogram 2, although 
some  adjustment  may  take  place  in  the  provincial  civil  service.  It  is  expected  that  basic  labor 
rights  of  affected  employees  will  be  protected.  Subprogram  2  will  reduce  the  gender  bias  in 
public sector employment and will contribute to achieving the goals of Punjab’s PRS paper.  A 
review of the environment implications was undertaken and no adverse environmental impacts 
were identified. Subprogram 2 will neither lead to any involuntary resettlement measures nor will 
it have any impact on indigenous people.  
 
C. 

Risks 

100.  The realization of these benefits and impacts will depend on a number of assumptions 
that are subject to a variety of risks. Mitigating measures have been integrated into the design of 
subprogram 2, taking into account lessons learned from subprogram 1. 
 
101.  Political  Risks.  Political  risks  in  Punjab  remain  comparatively  low.  The  elections  in 
October 2002 gave a clear majority to the party most closely associated with the administration 
that initiated Pakistan’s reform agenda. The Government and GOP remain strongly committed 
to the PRMP. However, political risks may evolve if macroeconomic achievements do not trickle 
down to the majority of voters. 
 
102.  Governance.  Subprogram  2  aims  to  reduce  abuses  of  power  and  rent-seeking 
opportunities.  Reforms  could  be  undermined  or  delayed  by  vested  interests  that  stand  to  lose 
from  greater  transparency  and  accountability.  However,  strong  ownership  and  support  for 
subprogram  2  at  the  highest  political  and  bureaucratic  levels  mitigates  this  risk.  A  new  CMU 
under the chief secretary of Punjab will be established to encourage more stakeholders within 
the civil service to participate and contribute to policy reforms. The Punjab Development Forum 
that began under subprogram 1 has institutionalized broad-based stakeholder participation and 
has also become an effective oversight mechanism. In addition, subprogram 2 design has been 
led and defined by GOP. Subprogram 2 interventions for civil service reforms are also expected 
to generate proactive support for reforms from the civil servants.  
 
103. 
implementation  demands  considerable 
institutional  capacity.  Insufficient  capacity  within  GOP  to  handle  the  envisaged  reforms  could 
impede  implementation.  The  ongoing  TA  loan  that  started  under  subprogram  1  will  be  made 
flexible  to  help  the  PMU  and  departments  to  overcome  capacity  limitations.  Emphasis  will  be 
given to strengthening the strategic planning process and to managing change to successfully 
implement the PRMP reforms. In addition, subprogram 2 expects the PMU to play a proactive
