Appendix 2 

SECTOR ANALYSIS 

Punjab’s Socioeconomic Performance  

 
A. 
 
Punjab had a total population of about 74 million in 1998 (the year of the last census), 
1. 
which is more than half the national total, and an estimated1 provincial gross domestic product 
(GDP)  of  about  57%  of  the  national  total.  The  GDP  growth  of  the  country  is  significantly 
determined by Punjab’s performance. In the recent national recovery, Punjab has been leading 
the  country.  Throughout  the  1990s,  Punjab’s  real  GDP  grew  by  4.5%  per  annum,  while 
Pakistan’s  growth  was  4.1%  per  annum.  As  Punjab’s  population  grew  by  about  2.4%  per 
annum, per capita income increased by about 2.1% per annum over the 1990s. This increase 
has not been shared equally. As a result, despite the relatively good economic performance of 
Punjab, it still houses most of the country’s poor.  
 
2. 
The  agriculture  sector  contributes  about  27%  of  provincial  GDP,  industry  22.5%,  and 
services 50.5%.2 The share of agriculture in Punjab’s GDP is slightly higher than its share in the 
national  GDP,  while  the  share  of  industry  is  slightly  lower.  This  is  not  surprising,  given  that 
Punjab has one of the largest canal networks in the world and a very fertile and deep top soil 
cover.  
 
Given  the  stable  macroeconomic  environment,  and  the  “fiscal  space”  available  at  the 
3. 
national level, Punjab has a good opportunity to ensure that it moves on a path of sustainable 
growth by ensuring suitable policy and institutional reforms. The Punjab Economic Report notes 
that:  “The  Government  of  the  Punjab  (GOP)  has  indicated  the  main  elements  of  its  economic 
strategy.  This  rests  on  five  pillars:  (i)  improving  governance;  (ii)  strengthening  fiscal  and 
financial  structures;  (iii)  creating  a  more  supportive  environment  for  private  sector-led  growth; 
(iv)  reforming  the  delivery  of  public  services;  and  (v)  addressing  the  provincial  economy’s 
vulnerability  to  shocks.”3  The  Punjab  Resource  Management  Program  Subprogram1  allowed 
the GOP to move on some of these elements. Subprogram 2 will build on the reform foundation 
laid by subprogram 1.  
 

1. 

Agriculture 

 
4. 
Agriculture provides 28% of Punjab’s output and 40% of its employment. Punjab has a 
grain surplus and helps feed other provinces. It also earns significant foreign exchange through 
rice and cotton exports. Agriculture is also the main feeder for the largest industry in the country: 
textiles. However, over the last decade and a half, employment in agriculture has been falling, 
and growth rates, although positive, have been in the 4–5% range. The green revolution of the 
1960s  increased  inputs  through  the  use  of  high-yield  variety  seeds,  better  fertilizer,  and 
pesticides. These measures have been adopted in over 80% of the irrigated land. Nevertheless, 
the sector is still characterized by low productivity in terms of efficiency of use of resources and 
inputs.  Yields  in  Punjab  (and  in  Pakistan  as  a  whole)  continue  to  be  well  below  the  potential 
assessed values.  
 
A major challenge for GOP over the next few years will be the introduction of the private 
5. 
sector  in  agricultural  marketing,  storage,  transportation,  grading,  packaging,  and  export  areas. 
                                                 
1  Estimates and estimation methodology are given in:  Government of the Punjab, World Bank, Asian Development 
Bank, Department for International Development of the United Kingdom. 2005. Punjab Economic Report. Towards 
a Medium-Term Development Strategy. Lahore.  

2  Footnote 1, p.  2. 
3  Footnote 1. p. 1. 

  

Appendix 2     

 33

Traditionally, these areas have been either monopolized by the state or very heavily regulated. 
GOP opened these areas to the private sector a few years ago, but the pace of reform has been 
slow  and  uneven.  Subprogram  2  has  identified  some  agricultural  subsectors  where  the  GOP 
needs to move quickly to provide the right regulatory environment for private sector entry. 
 

2. 

Industry and Non-Farm Sectors 

 
6. 
Almost  nine    out  of  10  people  employed  in  Punjab  work  in  the  private  sector.  Private 
sector  development  is  the  only  way  the  province  can  ensure  job  creation,  development,  and 
poverty  reduction.  The  non-farm  sectors  (manufacturing,  construction,  wholesale  and  retail 
trade,  and  transport  and  other  services)  contributed  around  two  thirds  of  the  total  provincial 
GDP  in  2003.  While,  in  percentage  terms,  agricultural  employment  has  declined  in  Punjab, 
employment in industry increased by 1.7 million and in services by 2.3 million during the 1990s. 
Combined, these sectors now employ more people than the agriculture sector. Punjab has the 
largest number of the country’s small and medium-sized enterprises. Since most employment in 
the private sector is in microenterprises in Punjab (as in the remaining parts of the country), the 
strategy for the non-agriculture sector has to ensure that special attention is paid to small and 
medium-sized enterprises. The GOP has already taken a few steps in this direction, some under 
subprogram 1, and more will be identified in subprogram 2.  
 
Punjab  contains  some  of  the  fastest  growing  urban  areas  of  the  country.  Lahore,  the 
7. 
provincial  capital,  is  a  prime  destination  for  investment  and  in-country  migration.  Faisalabad, 
Gujrat, Gunranwala, Rawalpindi, Sahiwal, Sheikhupura, and Sialkot are also growing rapidly. As 
a  result,  there  is  significant  potential  for  job  creation  and  growth  in  urban  development  and 
construction.  However,  this  needs  to  be  tapped  and  the  province  has  to  incentivize  the 
development of urban areas to ensure optimal growth. The current regulatory structures, rules 
and  laws  pertaining  to  buildings,  urban  property  taxes,  and  other  areas  related  to  urban 
development are outdated and sometimes archaic. These need to be streamlined to bring them 
in line with the existing and future requirements. 
 
8. 
Given current macroeconomic stability, the province has a good window of opportunity to 
capitalize on developing some of its potential in non-farm related areas, such as manufacturing, 
construction, and services. Punjab will need to prioritize the development of the private sector in 
these areas. Subprogram 2  will identify the need  for reforms in (i) public–private partnerships, 
(ii) private sector development, (iii) the regulatory framework for urban development, and (iv) the 
regulatory framework for urban land transfers and titling. Some of these issues need to be taken 
up with the federal government. The reforms identified under subprogram 2 will only pertain to 
areas within the domain of GOP.  
  

3. 

Social Sectors in Punjab 

 
Pakistan  ranks  142nd  in  the  human  development  index  out  of  a  total  of  177  countries.4 
9. 
On  some  of  the  more  specialized  indices,  like  the  health  or  corruption  index,  Pakistan  fares 
even more poorly. In the social sector, Punjab ranks fairly well compared to other provinces, but 
compared to the social sectors in other developing countries its performance is not good.  

10. 
The social sectors are closely tied to the quality of life of citizens. Much more investment 
is needed if Pakistan is to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). Since one of the 

                                                 
4   Pakistan  ranks  142  out  of  177  countries  in  the  Human  Development  Index.  Its  low  ranking  compared  to  other 
countries  with  similar  level  of  income  indicates  the  low  priority  that  social  sectors  have  historically  received.  See 
Mahbub ul Haq Human Development Centre. 2004. Human Development in South Asia 2004. Karachi. 

  
34 

Appendix 2 

main  aims  of  subprogram2  is  poverty  reduction  and  facilitating  rapid  progress  towards 
achievement  of  the  MDGs,  social  sector  monitoring  in  essential.  When  subprogram  1  was 
designed and implemented, Punjab lacked some basic social statistics. The following analysis is 
based  on  the  multiple  indicator  cluster  survey,  2003-04,  conducted  by  GOP,  in  collaboration 
with the federal government and the United Nations International Children Fund.   
 
11. 
Literacy  and  Education.  In  education,  Punjab  is  faring  better  than  other  provinces. 
However,  the  literacy  rate  is  only  54%,  and  net  enrollment  ratios  for  primary,  middle,  and 
secondary level are low. Gender differences continue to be fairly significant in Punjab, (except 
for  middle  schools)  and  there  are  significant  variations  between  districts,  where  literacy  rates 
range from 80% to 40%. The federal and provincial governments have increased allocations for 
education  and  the  Punjab  education  sector  reform  program  is  already  being  successfully 
implemented. New enrollments and awareness of education have increased. 
 
12. 
The  private  sector  has  expanded  rapidly.  According  to  one  estimate,  some  30%  of 
children attending schools in Punjab now go to private sector.5 It has also been shown in some 
surveys that private schools, even those with fees comparable with those in the public sector, 
deliver better education than their public counterparts.6 This does not imply that there is no role 
for public schools. On the contrary, the public sector can provide funding for schooling, while the 
management and provision of schooling can be organized in several ways. Subprogram 2 will 
identify  ways  in  which  the  education  sector  can  be  further  strengthened.  This  will  include 
providing a better framework for public–private partnerships, encouraging GOP to pilot options 
to assess their feasibility, and strengthening policy-making at the provincial level.   
 
Health. As in education, Punjab’s performance compares well with that of the rest of the 
13. 
country. However, the data is not impressive and demonstrate the relative neglect of the sector. 
There  are  very  significant  differences  between  districts.  Only  33%  of  births  are  attended  by  a 
skilled  health  worker,  and  in  some  districts  the  percentage  is  as  low  as  7%.  Contraceptive 
prevalence is low everywhere. Under-5 mortality is higher in Punjab than in other provinces and 
oral  rehydration  therapy  usage  is  lower.  About  34%  of  children  in  Punjab  are  not  covered  by 
immunization services, and in the worst performing district this increases to 81%.  
 
If  the  province  is  going  to  achieve  the  health-related  MDGs,  it  clearly  has  to  (i)  accord 
14. 
the  health  sector  a  higher  priority,  (ii)  increase  expenditure  on  the  sector,  (iii)  find  ways  of 
extending  the  service  to  more  people,  and  (iv)  ensure  better  quality  of  health  services. 
Subprogram  2  will  address  some  of  these  objectives,  especially  by  facilitating  the  entry  of 
private sector in provision, quality assurance, and third party monitoring and evaluation.  
 
15.  Water and Sanitation. Data in this sector is not very reliable. Multiple indicator cluster 
survey data report that 97% of Punjab has access to improved drinking water, but in 2005, even 
Lahore, the provincial capital and the largest city of the province, experienced several disease 
outbreaks  caused  by  contaminated  water.  Although  the  population  has  fairly  good  access  to 
drinking water sources, the same is not true for sanitation. Solid waste management is clearly 
underprovided,  and  sanitation  coverage  is  low.  There  are  significant  differences  between 
districts.  Water  and  waste  management  has  traditionally  been  a  state-provided  area,  and 
continues  to  be  so.  Subprogram  2  will  introduce  legal  and  institutional  mechanisms  to  allow

16. 
Social  Sectors,  Devolution,  and  Punjab  Resource  Management  Program.  The 
provision  of  education  up  to  secondary  level;  primary  and  tertiary  health  care;  and  water  and 
sanitation have been devolved to the districts. In fact, water and sanitation provision has been 
devolved to the tehsil level.7 However, the province retains the power to formulate policy, set the 
regulatory framework, and to plan and implement vertical programs for these sectors. There are 
a  number  of  federal  vertical  programs  especially  in  health.  Subprogram  2  cannot  bind  the 
districts or tehsils since it has been negotiated exclusively with the province. Hence, it restricts 
itself  to  suggesting  policy  reforms  in  those  areas  that  are  within  the  mandate  of  the  provincial 
government,  particularly  introducing  the  private  sector  in  construction  of  facilities,  provision  of 
services, quality monitoring and evaluation, and third party verifications.  
 

4. 

The Employment and Growth Challenge 

 
The  labor  force  of  Punjab  was  estimated  at  about  27  million  in  2002.8  About  70%  was 
17. 
rural,  80%  male,  and  60%  self-employed.  The  public  sector  employed  only  about  11%  of  the 
labor  force  (however,  18%  of  urban  female  workers  are  employed  by  the  public  sector).  The 
private  sector,  including  the  informal  sector,  provides  most  of  the  employment  in  Punjab.  The 
Punjab Economic Report states that almost 86% of workers are employed in microenterprises 
employing fewer than five workers. During the past decade, there has been a significant drop in 
the  percentage  of  the  workforce  employed  in  agriculture  (from  51.1%  to  42.8%).  Meanwhile, 
there have been increases in manufacturing (11.3% to 15.7%), community and social services 
(13.2%  to  14.8%),  wholesale  and  retail  trade  (12.1%  to  14.1%),  and  transport,  storage  and 
communication (4.5% to 5.4%) sectors. This is in line with literature on employment transitions 
associated with economic development.  
 
Real  Earnings  of  Labor  Declined  Over  the  Latter  Part  of  the  1990s.  The  biggest 
18. 
decline  in  real  earnings  was  in  wages  for  casual  labor.  There  is  some  evidence  of  increasing 
reliance  on  casual  and  contract  labor  even  in  most  formal  sectors,  which  has  increased  the 
uncertainty of income for laborers. Recent economic growth has meant some gains in wages, 
but  for  this  to  be  sustained  better  jobs  need  to  be  created  and  there  need  to  be  significant 
increases  in  productivity  in  most  sectors.  The  labor  force  in  Punjab  will  continue  to  grow  at 
about  3%  per  annum  for  the  next  decade  until  it  reaches  about  36  million  by  2011–12. 
According  to  various  government  labor  force  surveys,  unemployment  in  the  province  has 
increased  over  the  past  15  years. The  unemployment  rate  was  around  3%  in  1984–85,  and it 
had reached 8.5% by 2001–02 (about 2.3 million people). Although the recent recovery has led 
to a slight decrease to 7.4% (labor force survey, 2003–04), about 10 million new productive and 
well-paying jobs need to be created by 2011–12.  

 
5. 

The Poverty Challenge 

 
19. 
As  with  Pakistan,  poverty  in  Punjab  declined  rapidly  in  the  1980s  but  increased 
significantly in the 1990s. By 2002, poverty had increased to 34.1% (compared with the national 
estimate  of  37.1%)  and  incidence  was  much  higher  in  rural  areas.  Of  people  living  in  rural 
areas,  37%  fall  below  the  poverty  line  (the  national  figure  is  41.6%),  while  only  27%  of  urban 
Punjabis fall below the poverty line (the national figure is 26.4%).

Institutional Framework and Government Responsibilities  

Punjab can be divided into three regions: north, central, and south.9 Although the overall 
20. 
poverty level in the province was 34.1% in 2001–02, it was 29.8% in the north region, 31.8% in 
central,  and  40.4%  in  south.  For  rural  poverty,  the  figures  were  37%  overall;  33.8%,  south; 
35.3%, central; and 40.8%, south. For urban areas, figures were 27.4% overall; 20.1%, north; 
24.6%,  central;  and  38.7%,  south.  Not  only  is  the  south  poorer,  its  socioeconomic  indicators 
(urbanization, literacy, health, infrastructure, and development of industry) are worse. Any anti-
poverty strategy must take these regional disparities into account.  
 
B.  
 
21. 
Constitutional  Provisions.  The  allocation  of  responsibilities  between  the  federal  and 
provincial governments is specified in the Fourth Schedule (under Article 4) of the Constitution 
of Pakistan of 1973. The Federal Legislative List sets out the functions to be performed by the 
Government, while the Concurrent List delineates the functions that can be performed either by 
the federal or the provincial governments. In the event of any conflict between the legislation of 
the  two  tiers  of  government,  that  of  the  federal  government  prevails.  Residual  functions,  not 
enumerated in either list, are the responsibility of the provinces.  
 
22. 
Federal Government Functions. According to the Federal Legislative List, the federal 
government  is  responsible  for  regulatory  as  well  as  service  functions.  In  addition,  the  federal 
government  is  currently  performing  several  functions  specified  in  the  Concurrent  List.10
  The 
weak  financial  position  of  provincial  governments  and  their  overwhelming  dependence  on 
federal grants and transfers greatly dilutes their ability to perform several of the functions in the 
Concurrent List. 
 
23. 
Provincial  Government  Functions.  Functions  not  mentioned  in  either  the  Federal 
Legislative  List  or  the  Concurrent  List  are  the  responsibility  of  the  provincial  governments. 
Provinces  have  sole  responsibility  for  law  and  order,  justice,  provincial  highways,  urban 
transport,  secondary  and  university  education,  agriculture  extension  and  provision  of  inputs, 
irrigation  and  land  reclamation,  industries,  and  mineral  resources.  The  provinces  undertake 
some of the functions in the Concurrent List, including social welfare, labor exchanges, training 
establishments, and management of historical monuments and sites. 
 
 
24. 
Local  Government  Functions  and  Decentralization  Reforms.  Punjab  Local 
Government Ordinance (PLGO), 2001, provides the basic political and administrative framework 
for  local  government.  District  governments  are  responsible  for  schools,  colleges,  and  district 
health  services;  and  tehsil  municipal  administrations  (TMAs)  for  water  supply  and  waste 
disposal, in coordination with union administrations. District governments are independent local 
governments, while TMAs and union administrations are autonomous corporate bodies. These 
new responsibilities require changes in the provincial structures for these services and will entail 
a transfer of human and financial resources from the province to local governments. Given the 
complexity  of  the  task,  the  transfer  of  powers  is  taking  place.  The  role  of  provincial  line 
departments  in  policy  making,  regulation,  standard  setting,  quality  control,  and  monitoring  has 
still not been brought in to conformity with local government legislation.

 37

Civil Service  

The  local  government  system  is  based  on  the  premise  that  if  locally  managed  basic 
25. 
services will be more responsive to local needs and service delivery will improve. During the first 
4  years  since  the  PLGO  came  into  force,  service  delivery  showed  signs  of  improvement, 
although  there  were  great  variations  among  districts.  The  district  government  budget  barely 
covers the fixed expenses for operating the services transferred to them. District governments 
have little control over provincial staff and staff transfers. There have been no allocations to the 
new  local  governments  from  the  provincial  development  budget.  Despite  problems  with  the 
release  of  funds  and  procedural  constraints,  local  governments’  use  of  the  fund  available  to 
them  has  been  satisfactory  in  most  cases.  However,  very  little  capacity-building  has  been 
undertaken and most has been at the district government level. TMAs and union administrations 
have  received  little  attention.  Under  the  Asian  Development  Bank-funded  Decentralization 
Support  Program11  and  other  external  assistance,  efforts  are  being  made  to  improve  the 
capacity  of  local  governments,  particularly  to  improve  financial  management  and  audits  of 
expenditures. The accountant general’s office is preparing appropriation accounts for the district 
governments. 
 
C. 
 
26. 
The  civil  service  in  Pakistan  used  to  consist  of  federal,  provincial,  and  local  council 
services.  Devolution  reform  has  created  a  third  tier  of  government  at  the  local  level12  but 
budgetary  and  administrative  controls  mean  that  personnel  management  remains  a  provincial 
function.  Federal  government  officers  hold  key  positions  at  provincial  and  district  levels 
(provincial  government  staff  also  hold  posts  in  district  governments).  The  dominant  feature  of 
civil  service  is  centralization  of  personnel  management  and  control  functions.  Accountability 
structures are weak and political interference is rife.  
 
27. 
Under  an  amendment  to  the  PLGO,  the  provincial  government  is  committed  to 
administratively realign its departments according to a structure outlined in the devolution plan 
by 31 December 2005. In addition, the amended PLGO calls for the creation of a district service 
and district and tehsil cadres by the same date. The purpose of the amendments is to relocate 
the  main  accountability  for  service  delivery  to  the  districts  and  to  empower  the  district 
governments  with  the  necessary  authority  to  ensure  that  services  are  delivered.  This  is  a 
substantial  and  complex  task  and  involves  reviewing  and  reorganizing  the  civil  service  at  all 
three levels of government. The review of the entire staffing needs at the local level will have to 
be  followed  up  with  the  establishment  of  a  legal  basis  for  new  district  service  and  cadres, 
including new arrangements for appointments, promotions, and transfers, in addition to ensuring 
the flow of financial and other resources to implement this undertaking. Federal and provincial 
inputs  into  district  service  delivery  management  will  need  to  be  rationalized  and  incentive 
structures put in place to attract the talent needed to manage the district level assignments. An 
appropriate mix of career and contract positions will have to be determined.  
 
28. 
Federal and provincial initiatives demonstrate enthusiasm for civil service reforms. A civil 
service  reform  unit  to  steer  civil  service  reform  has  been  established.  GOP  is  focusing  on  the 
capacity  building  of  its  civil  service  through  its  management  and  professional  development 
department.  The  World  Bank  is  helping  the  federal  government  to  develop  a  vision  for  civil 
service reform and to build the capacity of mid-career and senior public sector managers. The

D. 

Fiscal Restructuring and Financial Management 

29. 
Fiscal restructuring in order to increase development spending is the basis for improved 
public resource management. Punjab’s public finances have continued to suffer from structural 
rigidities  that  have  steadily  eroded  its  fiscal  base,  and  contributed  to  inadequate  service 
delivery.  The  issues  that  have  particularly  affected  public  finances  and  financial  management 
include  inflexibility  of  expenditures,  overstaffing,  overextension  of  the  governmental  mandate, 
vertical revenue-expenditure imbalances, inadequate fiscal transparency and weak monitoring, 
poorly  functioning  internal  controls,  weak  accounting  mechanisms,  and  delays  in  recording 
transactions.  In  particular,  the  weak  monitoring  of  budgets  has  eroded  their  usefulness  as 
instruments for implementing and updating government policies.  
 
Volatility  of  Transfers  from  the  Federal  Divisible  Pool.  The  National  Finance 
30. 
Commission  (NFC)  award  of  1997  rendered  provinces  more  vulnerable  to  fluctuations  in 
resource  transfers.  Previous  NFC  awards  had  given  provincial  governments  disproportionate 
shares  of  the  more  buoyant  federal  taxes,  including  customs  and  excise.  The  1997  award, 
however,  shifted  to  a  system  that  shares  federal  taxes  among  provinces  equally  through  a 
single divisible pool. Moreover, federal fiscal reforms reduced the collection of key taxes such 
as customs tariffs and income tax, thereby reducing the size of the divisible pool. At the same 
time, the monthly transfers to the provinces were linked to actual tax receipts of federal taxes in 
the previous month, making provincial governments vulnerable to seasonal fluctuations. Added 
to  this  uncertainty  is  the  federal  government’s  consistent  overestimation  of  revenues.  A  new 
NFC award is expected to become effective in 2006, with a 48% share of the divisible pool for 
the provinces. Shared tax transfers (from the divisible pool) account for 75–80% of total federal 
transfers to Punjab, with the remainder consisting of other direct transfers, loans, and grants. 
 
31. 
The  volatility  of  transfers  from  the  divisible  pool  has  also made  provincial  revenue  and 
expenditure  estimates  unrealistic.  Consequently,  there  has  been  a  build  up  of  federal 
government liabilities, with provincial governments lacking the funds to meet even their fiduciary 
obligations. All these developments have led to fiscal stress at federal and provincial levels.  
 
32. 
Given  that  most  expenditure  commitments  of  the  provincial  governments  are  for  fixed 
costs such as salaries and pensions, the seasonal fluctuations in resource transfers have had 
implications  for  expenditure  management  and  have  led  to  GOP  having  to  arrange  overdrafts 
from  the  State  Bank  of  Pakistan.  The  overall  budgetary  deficits  of  GOP  have  therefore  only 
been financed by building up arrears and by using off-budget funds held in a fiduciary capacity 
and reflected in the movement of the Public Fund Account. The outcome is the uncovered gap 
between the amount set by GOP to discharge its obligations in respect of the General Provident 
Fund and the actual liability on this account.  

Resource  Mobilization.  GOP  currently  collects  about  27%  of  the  total  receipts  it 
33. 
utilizes, with the remainder coming from federal transfers and grants. Of the taxes collected by 
GOP,  35%  are  direct  and  65%  indirect.  The  most  important  are  duties  on  stamps  (indirect), 
representing  29.2%  of  the  taxes  raised  by  GOP;  motor  vehicle  tax  (indirect),  16%;  urban 
immovable  property  tax  (direct),  15.6%;  land  revenue,  13.2%;  sales  tax  on  services  (indirect), 
6.8%; and electricity duty (indirect), 6.3%; and agricultural income tax, 5.1%.

Expenditure  Management.  GOP  cannot  fund  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M) 
34. 
expenditures  or  undertake  capital  investments  in  high-priority  areas.  This  has  led  to  a  sharp 
deterioration of key physical and social infrastructure, impairing prospects for growth. There is a 
significant backlog of infrastructure requiring regular repair and maintenance.  
 
35. 
In  general,  there  are  significant  weaknesses  in  the  auditing  and  reporting  functions  of 
GOP that make it difficult to accurately assess costs and expenditures in key sectors. There are 
typically substantial discrepancies between revised estimates, estimates from the civil accounts, 
and estimates from the appropriation accounts. The civil accounts, which are records of actual 
expenditure,  are  not  published  by  GOP,  and  therefore,  it  is  not  possible  to  assess  whether 
budgetary  releases  have  actually  been  spent  properly.  A  comprehensive  analysis  of 
expenditures  is  a  cumbersome  exercise.  The  Punjab  Public  Financial  Management  and 
Accountability Assessment in May 2005 recorded that the system through which public services 
obtained  most  of  their  resources  did  not  function  efficiently.  It  noted  significant  procedural 
delays  in  the  system  that  hindered  the  spending  powers  of  the  executive.  These  included  a 
lengthy  procurement  process;  many  committees,  which  slow  down  decision-making;  lack  of 
incentives for taking timely decisions; and duplicate controls through pre-audit processes. 
 
36.  Multiyear  budgeting  is  a  prerequisite  for  estimating  the  funds  needed  to  complete 
ongoing projects. GOP  has already started to restructure its finances and is considering other 
measures  to  achieve  the  goals  of  the  medium-term  budget  framework.  To  improve  budgetary 
practices  and  ensure  the  attainment  of  medium-  and  long-term  goals,  GOP  has,  with  the 
assistance  of,  Department 
International  Development,  already  started  performance 
budgeting in, among others, the education, health, and agriculture sectors. 
 
E.  
 
37. 
The  institutionalization  of  efficient  development  planning  and  resource  allocation 
systems  is  key  to  effective  public  policy.  In  Pakistan,  and  in  Punjab  in  particular,  the  systems 
are cumbersome, outdated, and may actually hinder implementation of development initiatives.  
 
38. 
Administrative  Budget  Preparation  Exercise.  GOP’s  budgets  focus  on  nominal 
expenditures rather than on outputs. This, combined with inadequately maintained accounts and 
ineffectual  monitoring,  have  weakened  the  link  between  allocations  and  outcomes,  making 
budget  preparation  a  routine,  administrative  exercise  that  is  not  linked  to  policy  objectives. 
Budget  allocations  continue  to  be  made  incrementally,  rather  than  in  the  wider  frame  of 
medium-term priorities and poverty goals. The bulk of budgetary expenditures (about 75% of the 
total) are classified as permanent recurrent expenditures, which are rarely reviewed to establish 
their relevance to GOP’s development priorities.  
 
Identification  and  Approval  of  Development  Schemes.  The  Planning  and 
39. 
Development  Department  (P&DD)  issues  a  directive  and  guidelines  to  all  departments  at  the 
end of the second quarter of the fiscal year, asking them to recommend development schemes 
for inclusion in the annual development program. Each department submits estimates for next 
year’s development expenditure to P&DD in the form of draft demands for funds. 
 
40. 
As the third quarter of the fiscal year closes, the draft demands are reviewed by P&DD. 
Before  1998,  the  bulk  of  provincial  development  schemes  were  funded  by  the  federal 
government through cash development loans. The federal government stopped providing cash 
development  loans  to  provincial  governments  in  1998.  Nevertheless,  the  approval  of  the 
Planning  Commission  is  still  required  for  all  schemes  of  over  PRs200  million.  In  Punjab,  all

development schemes over PRs20 million are approved by the provincial development working 
party,  chaired  by  a  representative  of  P&DD,  although  development  schemes  are  now

development committees. Similarly, all schemes that have a component of foreign funding are 
approved  by  the  Provincial  Development  Working  Party.  Thus,  in  spite  of  devolution  of

described above has the following flaws:

Once approved, development schemes are not necessarily funded as part of the 
annual  development  program.  There  is  no  coherent  link  between  approval  and 
allocation  of  funds.  While  a  certain  degree  of  overprogramming  is  advisable  to 
ensure  that  funds  are  not  left  unused,  the  system  of  according  approval  to 
funds  makes  planning  process 
projects  without  ensuring  availability  of 
meaningless. Given that the bulk of the annual development program resources 
are  used  to  fund  ongoing  schemes,  most  of  which  are  subject  to  cost  and  time 
overruns, preparing new schemes and having them approved is a wasted effort. 

The  absence  of  a  link  between  approval  and  allocation  creates  a  discrepancy 
between  actual  and  required  allocations  for  projects  in  the  annual  development 
program.  Annual  required  allocations  as  specified  in  the  Planning  Commission 
pro  forma  I  (PC-I)  of  projects  are  included  in  the  annual  development  program, 
which means schemes are often not completed on time or within the original cost 
estimates.  Moreover,  links  between  initial  and  recurrent  costs  of  new  projects 
have not been established through well-defined procedures. While the PC-Is give 
estimates of future recurrent costs, there is no procedure for ensuring that these 
are  reflected  in  subsequent  recurrent  expenditures  funded  by  the  Finance 
Department. This results in a disconnection between development and recurrent 
budgets, with obvious consequences in the form of mismatches.    

 
41. 
The provincial planning process is thus characterized by rigidities and structural defects 
leading  to  distortions  in  project  portfolio.  Development  budgets  or  annual  development 
expenditures  are  considered  more  important  than  recurrent  expenditure,  primarily  for  political 
reasons. As a result, the service infrastructure created by GOP has expanded, while resources 
available for non-salary operation and maintenance have decreased, leading to deterioration in 
service delivery.  
 
Incremental Demands. P&DD’s instructions to departments specify that the increase in 
42. 
draft demands have to be within a certain percentage increase of the previous year’s allocations 
(for  FY2004  it  was  20%).  There  is  a  tendency  for  departments  to  prepare  draft  demands 
according  to  this  “formula”,  i.e.,  adding  to  last  year’s  allocations  up  to  the  ceiling  specified 
without considering whether the level of expenditure is required or can be accommodated. This 
strategy has advantages for the departments, as  it provides access to limited resources given 
that P&DD tries to accommodate the maximum number of schemes in the annual development 
program,  even  if  the  resources  are  allocated  are  far  below  the  required  amounts  for  each 
scheme. The departments use their draft demands to claim future resource allocations, without 
considering the status of the underfunded and incomplete ongoing programs.

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE GRANT FOR SUPPORT FOR SUBPROGRAM 3  
OF THE PUNJAB RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 

Purpose and Output 

 Background and Rationale 

 
 
A.  
 
1. 
The  Government  of  Pakistan  (the  Government)  and  the  Government  of  the  Punjab 
(GOP)  launched  a  major  governance  program  in  2000.  The  Punjab  Resource  Management 
Program (PRMP) is a continuation of these efforts. Subprogram 1 was successfully completed 
and  subprogram  2  will  continue  policy  dialogue  to  improve  Punjab’s  governance  mechanisms 
and systems.   
  
B. 
 
2. 
The  purpose  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  grant  is  to  provide  advice  for  the 
implementation  of  subprogram  2  and  for  further  broad-based  policy  reforms  through  the 
preparation of subprogram 3. Policy reforms under the PRMP are divided into the three areas: 
(i) fiscal and financial management, (ii) processes and institutions for pro-poor service delivery, 
and (iii) private sector development. PRMP will achieve its purpose when policy reforms result in 
public  resource  management  that  is  efficient,  cost-effective,  transparent,  and  accountable  and 
leads to higher equity and sustainability. The TA will have four components. 
 
3. 
Fiscal and Financial Management (Component 1). A key responsibility of the program 
management  unit  (PMU)  is  to  provide  timely  advice  to  the  implementing  departments  and  to 
coordinate support for implementation targets. Experts will be engaged to facilitate (i) revenue 
and  expenditure  management;  (ii)  restructuring  of  public  debt  and  provincial  liabilities; 
(iii) analysis  of  inefficient  subsidies  and  options  for  phasing  them  out;  (iv)  improved 
accountability  and  financial  management  systems;  and  (v)  a  review  of  reforms  for  public 
procurement systems. 
 
4. 
Civil Service Reform (Component 2). To sustain the ongoing reforms, GOP will reform 
its human resource management. This component will support the GOP to (i) review and assess 
various  options  on  restructuring  the  provincial  civil  service;  (ii)  assist  in  the  preparation  of  a 
human  resources  policy;  (iii)  provide  technical  peer  review  for  amendments  to  the  legislation 
and  rules  of  the  provincial  public  service  commission;  and  (iv)  design  a  medium-  term 
departmental restructuring plan. In addition, this component will help the change management 
unit to circulate viable options for civil service reforms. 
 
5. 
Private  Sector  Development  (Component  3).  A  key  focus  of  subprogram  2  is  to 
facilitate  province-wide  reforms  for  private  sector  activities,  forging  public–private  partnerships 
and reducing GOP’s direct involvement in commercial activities. Under this component, TA will 
be provided to (i) draft laws, regulations and rules required to effect changes in the legal regime 
that  impedes  private  sector  growth  in  Punjab;  (ii)  prepare  templates  for  public–private 
partnerships; (iii) design provincial and local government innovations in business processes to 
encourage  the  inclusion  of  private  sector  in  service  delivery;  (iv)  help  the  provincial  and  local 
governments to privatize and outsource agriculture-related functions; and (v) prepare options for 
privatizing public sector organizations.

Appendix 9                    

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY 
AND POVERTY IMPACT ASSESSMENT 

Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy  

 
A. 
 

1. 

Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 

that 

included  civil  society.  The  PRS  paper 

 
1. 
In  the  aftermath  of  the  steeply  increasing  incidence  of  poverty  during  the  1990s,  the 
Government of the Punjab (GOP) produced a poverty reduction strategy (PRS) paper. This was 
based  on  an  in-depth  quantitative  and  qualitative  analysis  of  poverty  in  the  province  and  an 
extensive  consultative  process 
identified 
(i) governance  reform,  (ii)  strengthening  of  planning  capability,  (iii)  improvements  to  service 
delivery, (iv) fiscal and financial reform, (v) income and employment generation, and (vi) gender 
mainstreaming as key elements of effective poverty reduction in Punjab. The Punjab Resource 
Management  Program  (PRMP)  aims  to  cover  each  of  these.  Subprogram  1  of  the  PRMP  has 
already helped to produce poverty-focused investment strategies for six key sectors in order to 
implement the Punjab PRS. 
 
In  an  earlier  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  poverty  assessment  for  Pakistan,1  poor 
2. 
governance was identified as the key cause of poverty in  Pakistan. Poor governance not only 
resulted  in  poor  public  service  delivery  and  greater  vulnerability,  but  also  led  to  a  drop  in 
business confidence, which in turn resulted in lower investment levels and growth. The poverty 
assessment was the main input for the country strategy and program, 2002–2006,2 which laid 
out ADB’s medium-term development strategy for Pakistan. The country strategy and program 
was  developed  in  the  context  of  the  national  PRS  paper  and  the  efforts  to  create  a  feasible 
monitoring  framework  linked  to  the  budget  and  the  International  Monetary  Fund's  poverty 
reduction  and  growth  facility.  In  2004,  Pakistan  successfully  graduated  from  the  poverty 
reduction and growth facility.  
 

2. 

Poverty Analysis: Poverty and Public Resource Management in Punjab 

 
3. 
Although there are several initiatives in Punjab for improving the quality and provision of 
service delivery, obstacles remain. Services are insufficient and their quality leaves much to be 
desired, which increases poverty. Inadequate public services and large social service deficits in 
health and education, combined with traditionally inadequate budgets for maintenance of roads, 
irrigation systems, water supply schemes, and other infrastructure, have contributed directly to 
low  economic  growth,  poor  social  indicators,  and  an  inability  to  reduce  poverty.  Poor  service 
delivery is tied to declining public sector expenditures and to poor incentives for service delivery. 
However, it is encouraging that levels of investment in the social sector have recently increased. 
The Punjab Education Sector Reform Program (funded by the World Bank) focuses on pro-poor 
initiatives, including the provision of free books and stipends to girl students as part of efforts to 
increase  enrollments  and  retention  in  poor  districts.  Interventions  under  the  Decentralization 
Support Program3 and the Devolved  Social Services Program (DSSP)4 are building capacities 
at provincial and local government levels for efficient and effective pro-poor service delivery with 
better monitoring, evaluation, and gender sensitivity. There have been major accomplishments

 Appendix 9 

61

under  subprogram  1,  including  the  development  of  poverty-focused  investment  strategies  for 
key social sectors. 
 
4. 
Subprogram  1  has  helped  to  reduce  the  high  debt  service  burden  through  early 
retirement of cash development loans. The initial restructuring of provincial taxes has resulted in 
an increase in revenues, although Punjab still feels fiscal squeeze with low revenues and high 
establishment costs. Almost 80% of provincial current expenditures are committed to pensions, 
interest payments, subsidies, wages, and grants to local governments. The annual development 
program  is  still  overloaded  with  ongoing  projects  that  entail  a  large  “throw  forward”  of 
expenditure liabilities. The budget process focus on inputs and the inability to prioritize or review 
most  expenditure  items,  combined  with  the  tendency  to  enforce  damaging  short-term 
expenditure controls to address the fiscal squeeze, have seriously reduced the effectiveness of 
public expenditures in Punjab. The continuity of reforms in underlying systems and processes to 
manage  public  resources  is  crucial  if  the  incidence  of  poverty  in  Punjab  to  be  arrested  and 
reversed.  
 

3. 

Participation Process 

a. 

Stakeholder Analysis  

 
The  outcomes  of  stakeholder  consultations  at  all  three  levels  of  government  and  civil 
5. 
society  have  been  incorporated  into  the  design  of  the  PRMP.  Lessons  learned  during  the 
consultative process for the preparation of the Decentralization Support Program and the DSSP 
have also been included.  
 
6. 
The  PRMP  approach  was  the  result  of  policy  dialogue  which  began  in  2002  with  ADB 
technical  assistance  (TA).5  The  PRMP  is  built  on  a  continuous  policy  dialogue,  which  will 
continue  upto  2008.  All  key  stakeholders,  including  politicians,  civil  servants,  civil  society 
organizations,  media,  private  sector  representatives  and  other  partner  organizations,  are 
regularly consulted. The cluster approach, with regular dialogue, has ensured that the reforms, 
despite being demanding, have stayed broadly on track. 
 
An  important  feature  of  the  PRMP  is  its  support  for  the  Punjab  Development  Forum 
7. 
(PDF). This is now is a well established and regular event which brings all stakeholders together 
to (i) study and evaluate development progress in Punjab, (ii) discuss key challenges, and (iii) 
provide guidance on how to meet development challenges.6  
 

b. 

Participation Strategy 

 
8. 
One  of  the  central  themes  in  GOP’s  current  efforts  at  poverty  reduction  is  its 
participatory approach, and the Punjab PRS paper was formulated on the basis of wide-ranging 
consultations  with  major  stakeholders.  GOP’s  commitment  to  participation  is  reflected  in  the 
ongoing  reform  effort,  which  emphasizes  consultation  through  initiatives  such  as  the  PDF. 
Consultations  were  a  regular  feature  of  subprogram  1  and  included  the  Medium-Term  Budget 
Framework  (MTBF)  Forum  in  October  2004.  PRMP  is  designed  to  (i) ensure  that  the  systems 
and procedures in the public sector promote accessibility, accountability and transparency; and 
(ii) devote  considerable  resources  to  developing  the  capacities  of  provincial  government

officials,  elected  representatives,  and  local  government  administrators.  With  clear  evidence  of 
participatory  approaches  gaining  ground  in  government  processes,  there  is  an  urgent  need  to 
institutionalize of wider stakeholder participation with the support of the political leadership and 
bureaucracy.  
 
9. 
In line with the recommendations of evaluations of other policy-based lending, the PRMP 
will  continue  to  convene  the  PDF  and  to  conduct  other  participatory  processes  engaging 
stakeholders at federal, provincial, and local levels. The PRMP receives oversight and guidance 
through a high-level steering committee, which includes representatives of civil society and the 
private sector. As the reform process under PRMP deepens, the role of the steering committee 
will  become  central  to  its  success;  more  vigorous  and  regular  direction  from  the  steering 
committee will be required under subprogram 2. 
 

4. 

Social Issues 

 
10. 
The  Punjab  PRS  paper  highlighted  the  need  to  set  up  of  a  system  of  monitoring  and 
evaluating social and economic conditions. The paper identified key indicators, baselines, and 
targets, and clearly defined the responsibility for collection of data related to each indicator. The 
ADB  TA  on  Local  Government  Performance  Enhancement7  and  Gender  and  Governance 
Mainstreaming8  also  established  baselines  and  targets  for  gender,  access,  equity,  and 
sustainability. In addition, the TA on Enhancing Capacity for Poverty  Reduction and Resource 
Management in Punjab9 provides for the engagement of a monitoring and evaluation specialist 
who  will  work  with  GOP  to  develop  key  performance  indicators  to  monitor  progress  against 
social sector targets. The work on monitoring and evaluation has been done under previous TA 
and  the  DSSP  is  encouraging.  The  executing  agency  of  the  PRMP,  the  Planning  and 
Development  Department  (P&DD),  intends  to  undertake  a  major  capacity  building  initiative  to 
improve its monitoring and evaluation systems and processes, including those carried out by the 
Punjab Economic Research Institute and the Bureau of Statistics.  
 

a. 

Gender 

 
11. 
Recent  data  from  the  Pakistan integrated  household  survey,  2000-01,  and  the  multiple 
indicator  cluster  survey,  2003-04,  confirm  the  wide  gender  disparities  in  Punjab  in  relation  to 
access to basic social services, such as health and education, and employment opportunities. 
Large  disparities  persist  across  urban  and  rural  sectors  and  across  different  income  levels. 
These  disparities  are  higher  in  rural  areas.  Reported  labor  force  participation  by  women  is 
extremely low. 
 
12. 
A  preliminary  gender  review  of  federal,  provincial,  and  district  level  public  sector 
expenditure and its management suggests a critical need for cross-sector and comprehensive 
gender analysis, planning, budgeting, auditing, and monitoring systems, and a methodology and 
mechanisms  to  ensure  gender-balanced  resource  distribution  at  all  the  three  levels.  Fulfilling 
commitments on mainstreaming gender is one of the key objectives of the PRMP. The approval 
and  implementation  of  the  provincial  gender  reform  action  plan  (GRAP)  was  achieved  under 
subprogram  1.  A  PRs612  million  GRAP  Planning  Commission  pro  forma  I  (PC-I)  with  the 
objective of mainstreaming gender at all levels of the government has been approved by GOP.

63

 

 

b. 

Access 

 
13. 
The reforms proposed under PRMP will promote (i) improved public access to services, 
and (ii) access to timely reliable information on resource management issues. Public access to 
services will have a direct impact on improving the welfare of the poor while improving access to 
information will enhance the pro-poor focus of public expenditures. There will be positive direct 
impacts  from  greater  access  to  pro-poor  service  delivery.  Improved  governance  will  result  in 
lower  transaction  costs  as  rent-seeking  behavior  and  graft  are  reduced.  The  resulting  lower 
transaction costs will benefit the poor and the non-poor alike, which will improve access for all. 
The impact of the reforms carried out under subprogram 1 is already visible as key sectors now 
have  poverty-focused  investment  strategies  and  progress  has  been  made  towards  preparing 
budgets according to the MTBF. Subprogram 2 would help further refine and institutionalize the 
poverty-focused investment strategy. 
 
14. 
The  PRMP  aims  to  improve  effectiveness,  predictability,  and  accountability  in  financial 
management  by  ensuring  transparency  in  (i) the  budgeting  process,  (ii) intergovernmental 
financing, and (iii) procurement of goods and services. Affording access to this information to all 
stakeholders will improve public oversight and monitoring and help keep expenditures focused 
in a pro-poor direction. Improving monitoring, feedback, and evaluation systems will ensure that 
decisions  are  based  on  analysis  of  widely  understandable  and  available  information  about 
prevailing conditions and that information is not the privilege of the few to be used for personal 
or political expediency. Both aspects of access—to services and to information—are critical for 
the success of the PRMP and will feature prominently in subprogram 2.  
 

c. 

Equity 

 
15. 
Equity is the main consideration of the PRMP, and it therefore supports the phasing out 
of subsidies that do not explicitly target the poor. The PRMP will support more spending for pro-
poor  public  service  delivery  and  more  transparent  and  efficient  public  resource  management. 
Equity will be supported by making the public sector human resources management more merit- 
based. 
 
16. 
In  Pakistan,  there  are  often  horizontal  imbalances  across  local  government  units  with 
regard  to  resource  endowments.  The  PRMP  will  help  to  ensure  greater  equity  across  local 
governments.  A  more  proactive  criteria-based  approach  toward  resource  sharing  among  the 
districts  on  the  one  hand  and  between  the  province  and  the  districts  on  the  other  would  go  a 
long way towards rationalizing resource allocations and putting in place a more pro-poor focus. 
District level poverty-focused investment plans and programs will be supported.  
 

d. 

Sustainability 

 
17. 
ADB actively supports measures to improve effective resource management (which was 
identified  as  the  basis  for  poverty  reduction  in  Punjab  in  the  PRS  paper).  PRMP  has  already 
helped  bring  about  significant  reforms  in  development  planning  and  resource  management 
systems.  GOP  has  already  begun  important  reforms,  including  preparation  of  the  MTBF, 
taxation reforms, reforms in procurement of goods and services, improvements to the planning 
and approval process for development projects with a poverty focus, and the approval of a new 
industrial  policy  that  addresses  many  of  the  concerns  of  the  private  sector.  Initial  steps  to 
strengthen  the  pro-business  orientation  of  legal  instruments  and  to  reduce  bureaucratic 
discretion began under subprogram 1 and have already started to improve the business climate.

Subprogram  2  will  build  on  this  and  support  GOP  to  implement  the  essentially  homegrown 
reform agenda that was begun under subprogram 1. Given GOP’s strong sense of ownership of 
the reform process, the prospects for the long-term sustainability of the PRMP’s achievements 
are good.

B.  Poverty Analysis  
 
The  Punjab  Resource  Management  Program  is  a  central  element  of  the 
Punjab poverty reduction strategy paper to reduce the incidence of poverty 
in  Punjab  from  33%  in  1999  to  28%  in  2006.  The  Punjab  Resource 
Management  Program  is  supporting  the  three  components  of  Asian 
Development  Bank’s 
reduction  strategy:  pro-poor 
sustainable  economic  growth,  good  governance,  and  social  development. 
Pro-poor sustainable economic growth is to be achieved through measures 
that  increase  the  enabling  environment  for  private  sector  development. 
This,  in  turn,  will  promote  employment  opportunities  for  Pakistan’s  rapidly 
growing  population  and  raise  real  wages  of  the  working  poor.  To  support 
governance,  the  Program  will  increase  transparency  and  accountability  in 
utilization  of  funds,  and  develop  institutional  arrangements  and  processes 
that  allow 
investment 
programming. Improved fiscal management will provide space for financing 
high-priority  expenditures 
to  social 
development  will  come  about  through  enhanced  public  sector  allocations 
for health, education, or water supply and sanitation, as well measures that 
allow greater competition and participation by the private sector in service 
provision to improve service quality. Adjustments at the provincial level are 
particularly important to bring about as most of social development services 
that  impact  on  the  livelihood  off  the  poor  are  delivered  at  provincial  and 
district level.

D.  Gender Development 
 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
The program fully supports the implementation of the Gender Reform Action Plan (GRAP) in the Punjab. 

Has an output been prepared?  Yes 
Two specific assurances are included in the program:  
(i) The Government of the Punjab will provide continued policy and financial support for successful implementation of 
GRAP.  The  Government  of  the  Punjab  will  take  proactive  measures  to  (a)  strengthen  the  Woman  Development 
Department  at  the  provincial  and  district  level;  (b)  implement  cost-neutral  reforms,  such  as  reforms  to  increase 
women’s  employment  in  the  public  sector,  and  budgetary  reforms;  (c)  provide  required  budget  allocations  under 
revenue  and  development  budget  as  outlined  in  the  GRAP;  and  (d)  establish  incentive  grants  for  women’s 
development under Provincial Finance Commission, as approved under the GRAP.  
(ii) Gender considerations in reforms. The Change Management Unit will ensure to include gender considerations in 
all proposed reforms.
